Class ForexRecord

Packaged in : FX.Contract.jar

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description

      Constructor with Generic structure..

      Default constructor. Create an empty ForexRecord.

    • Method Detail

      • addAddlInfoMetal

        public void addAddlInfoMetal(java.lang.CharSequence param)
        Appends the specified AddlInfoMetal to the end of the collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This field is used to input additional information which corresponds to the Tag 72 on MT600,604,605 swift messages. Validation Rules: Multi-value field. 1-35 Alpha-numeric characters User can enter information in this field only if any of the fields among DELIVERY.DETAILS,METAL.TYPE and QUANTITY contains 'OTH'/'OTHR' Number of multi-values allowed on this field is based on the no of occurrence of 'OTH' value among the fields DELIVERY.DETAILS,METAL.TYPE and QUANTITY.

        Parameters:
        param - the AddlInfoMetal to append
        Returns:
        nothing

        public void addAddlRepInfo(TField param)

        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting info to a Trade Repository. Denotes the additional report info when the ACTION.TYPE is 'O' Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed and for FW or SW type FX contracts or when SUB.DEAL.TYPE is not 'IN' Validation Rules: This is a conditionally mandatory field Value to be entered only when ACTION.TYPE is 'O'

        Parameters:
        param - the AddlRepInfo to append
        Returns:

      • addConsolInd

        public void addConsolInd(java.lang.CharSequence param)
        Appends the specified ConsolInd to the end of the collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Indicates the consolidation keys which have been generated for this contract. One key will be generated for each currency (bought and sold) of the contract. Validation Rules: System generated. The first four parameters will always contain the Application ID (i.e. FX), the Currency Market, the Position Type and the Currency Code. The other parameters will default on the conditions defined in the file CONSOLIDATE.COND.

        Parameters:
        param - the ConsolInd to append
        Returns:
        nothing

Validation Rules: System generated. The first four parameters will always contain the Application ID (i.e. FX), the Currency Market, the Position Type and the Currency Code. The other parameters will default on the conditions defined in the file CONSOLIDATE.COND.

These details are for the benefit of the back office user. Validation Rules: 1-6 lines with up to 35 characters in each line.

      • addNotes

        public void addNotes(java.lang.CharSequence param)
        Appends the specified Notes to the end of the collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This element allows the user to record any special information or free form narrative. This narrative is for information only and will not be printed on the confirmation sent to the customer. These notes are for the benefit of the back/front office department and as such will not be output on the confirmation sent to the CPARTY. Validation Rules: 1-4 lines with up to 35 characters in each line.

        Parameters:
        param - the Notes to append
        Returns:
        nothing

      • addOverride

        public void addOverride(TField param)
        Appends the specified Override to the end of the collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Contains all the Override messages which the user agreed to during Input. During the validation stage of a Foreign Exchange contract, the system may provide the user with a series of screen override messages to indicate an anomaly, for instance, that the exchange rate varies by more than the variation tolerance defined in the CURRENCY table. In the event that the user confirms the Override, the full text of the actual Override Message will be stored, for reference purposes only, in this multivalue field. For example, if the user inserts an 'abnormal' exchange rate the field corresponding to the exchange rate then when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'VARIANCE OF RATE EXCEEDS PERMITTED TOLERANCE' This will draw the user's attention to the rate entered, which may be a mistake and can then be corrected, or, on the other hand, it may be correct input and so the user confirms that this rate is really intended. A second example might be in respect of a contract done with a client who has a credit line established with the bank but where the maturity date of the intended Foreign Exchange contract goes beyond the credit line expiry date. In this case when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'LINE EXPIRES BEFORE TXN MATURITY' Once again the user's attention is drawn to the situation and either corrected or confirmed via a positive response to the Override Message. If, subsequently, the contract record is either fully displayed or printed, then all override messages will be present. Validation Rules: Internal field. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        param - the Override to append
        Returns:
        nothing

      • addOverride

        public void addOverride(java.lang.CharSequence param)
        Appends the specified Override to the end of the collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Contains all the Override messages which the user agreed to during Input. During the validation stage of a Foreign Exchange contract, the system may provide the user with a series of screen override messages to indicate an anomaly, for instance, that the exchange rate varies by more than the variation tolerance defined in the CURRENCY table. In the event that the user confirms the Override, the full text of the actual Override Message will be stored, for reference purposes only, in this multivalue field. For example, if the user inserts an 'abnormal' exchange rate the field corresponding to the exchange rate then when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'VARIANCE OF RATE EXCEEDS PERMITTED TOLERANCE' This will draw the user's attention to the rate entered, which may be a mistake and can then be corrected, or, on the other hand, it may be correct input and so the user confirms that this rate is really intended. A second example might be in respect of a contract done with a client who has a credit line established with the bank but where the maturity date of the intended Foreign Exchange contract goes beyond the credit line expiry date. In this case when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'LINE EXPIRES BEFORE TXN MATURITY' Once again the user's attention is drawn to the situation and either corrected or confirmed via a positive response to the Override Message. If, subsequently, the contract record is either fully displayed or printed, then all override messages will be present. Validation Rules: Internal field. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        param - the Override to append
        Returns:
        nothing

      • addStmtNo

        public void addStmtNo(java.lang.CharSequence param)
        Appends the specified StmtNo to the end of the collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: A number generated automatically by the system which identifies either a statement entry or a category entry in respect of a contract. The system will automatically insert a number into this field and this number may refer to a statement entry or a category entry depending on the value contained in the corresponding multivalue fields. The following examples will illustrate the use of this field. Example 1: On the value date of a Foreign Exchange contract there will be an entry on the our account pay and the following type of number will be generated at this field: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1 The number automatically generated in Field 104.1 is unique to the contract in question and is built in the following way: 1. The first four digits '6737' indicate the number of days since the 1st of January 1968. In our example, it corresponds to the 11th of June 1986. 2. The next five digits '32684' indicate the number of seconds since midnight. In our example, it corresponds to an entry generated on line at 09:04:44 AM. 3. The last two digits '48' indicate the number of hundreds of seconds. The value assigned (again automatically) to field 154.2 identifies the number in 154.1 as a statement entry number. If the user wishes to call this statement entry record on to the screen the user will invoke the STMT.ENTRY Application and then type the following at 'AWAITING ID': 673732684.480001 where the suffix '0001' identifies it as the first statement entry (there may be more than one as the next example will illustrate). Example 2: A second example outlined here is similar to example 1 in that there is a statement entry on value date for both the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. The system handles this case as follows: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1-2 Once again field 154.1 contains the identification number automatically generated by the system while field 154.2 now contains two separate numbers signifying that there are in fact two separate statement entries, one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. If the user wishes to see either of these he must first of all invoke STMT.ENTRY followed by the desired function and then at 'AWAITING ID' type either: 673732684.480001 where the addition of the suffix '0001' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT PAY or 673732684.480002 where the addition of the suffix '0002' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT RECEIVE. Example 3: A third example might be that of a category entry generated at initiation of a contract where commission or charges have been debited to the customer and credited to a profit and loss category code. In this case the following entries are generated on the contract: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.3 STMT.NO ............ 1 Once again the standard type number is generated and inserted at field 154.1 Now, however, field 154.2 is replaced by Field 104.3 which now identifies the number in 154.1 as a category entry and not a statement entry. To call this category entry record onto the screen the user must now type: CATEG.ENTRY at 'AWAITING APPLICATION' followed by: 673732684.480001 at 'AWAITING ID'. Validation Rules: Internal multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        param - the StmtNo to append
        Returns:
        nothing

      • addStmtNo

        public void addStmtNo(TField param)
        Appends the specified StmtNo to the end of the collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: A number generated automatically by the system which identifies either a statement entry or a category entry in respect of a contract. The system will automatically insert a number into this field and this number may refer to a statement entry or a category entry depending on the value contained in the corresponding multivalue fields. The following examples will illustrate the use of this field. Example 1: On the value date of a Foreign Exchange contract there will be an entry on the our account pay and the following type of number will be generated at this field: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1 The number automatically generated in Field 104.1 is unique to the contract in question and is built in the following way: 1. The first four digits '6737' indicate the number of days since the 1st of January 1968. In our example, it corresponds to the 11th of June 1986. 2. The next five digits '32684' indicate the number of seconds since midnight. In our example, it corresponds to an entry generated on line at 09:04:44 AM. 3. The last two digits '48' indicate the number of hundreds of seconds. The value assigned (again automatically) to field 154.2 identifies the number in 154.1 as a statement entry number. If the user wishes to call this statement entry record on to the screen the user will invoke the STMT.ENTRY Application and then type the following at 'AWAITING ID': 673732684.480001 where the suffix '0001' identifies it as the first statement entry (there may be more than one as the next example will illustrate). Example 2: A second example outlined here is similar to example 1 in that there is a statement entry on value date for both the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. The system handles this case as follows: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1-2 Once again field 154.1 contains the identification number automatically generated by the system while field 154.2 now contains two separate numbers signifying that there are in fact two separate statement entries, one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. If the user wishes to see either of these he must first of all invoke STMT.ENTRY followed by the desired function and then at 'AWAITING ID' type either: 673732684.480001 where the addition of the suffix '0001' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT PAY or 673732684.480002 where the addition of the suffix '0002' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT RECEIVE. Example 3: A third example might be that of a category entry generated at initiation of a contract where commission or charges have been debited to the customer and credited to a profit and loss category code. To call this category entry record onto the screen the user must now type: CATEG.ENTRY at 'AWAITING APPLICATION' followed by: 673732684.480001 at 'AWAITING ID'. Validation Rules: Internal multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        param - the StmtNo to append
        Returns:
        nothing

      • addSwapRefNo

        public void addSwapRefNo(java.lang.CharSequence param)
        Appends the specified SwapRefNo to the end of the collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This field links together all legs of a swap deal by holding the reference number of each deal. It is generated automatically by the system and no operator input is allowed. On Swap deals, the Foreign Exchange Application will keep on each leg all the reference numbers of the various transactions which are part of the swap deal. This will allow the user to see on any leg of the contract, all other transactions involved in the swap deal. Validation Rules: Standard Foreign Exchange reference number. System generated. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        param - the SwapRefNo to append
        Returns:
        nothing

      • addSwapRefNo

        public void addSwapRefNo(TField param)
        Appends the specified SwapRefNo to the end of the collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This field links together all legs of a swap deal by holding the reference number of each deal. It is generated automatically by the system and no operator input is allowed. On Swap deals, the Foreign Exchange Application will keep on each leg all the reference numbers of the various transactions which are part of the swap deal. This will allow the user to see on any leg of the contract, all other transactions involved in the swap deal. Validation Rules: Standard Foreign Exchange reference number. System generated. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        param - the SwapRefNo to append
        Returns:
        nothing

        This field can be used only for Metal Trades. Validation Rules: 1-35 Alpha-numeric characters. Input mandatory for non ISDA type Agreements.

      • clearFxBulkOrdrId

        public void clearFxBulkOrdrId()
        Clear the collection of FxBulkOrdrId
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Indicate the FX.BULK.ORDER id reference through which FX transaction is created. It would be updated by the routine attached to OFS.SOURCE through FX transactions are created.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        nothing

      • clearIntFldId

        public void clearIntFldId()
        Clear the collection of IntFldId
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.
        Parameters:
        Returns:
        nothing

      • clearNotes

        public void clearNotes()
        Clear the collection of Notes
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This element allows the user to record any special information or free form narrative. This narrative is for information only and will not be printed on the confirmation sent to the customer. These notes are for the benefit of the back/front office department and as such will not be output on the confirmation sent to the CPARTY. Validation Rules: 1-4 lines with up to 35 characters in each line.

        Parameters:

        nothing

      • clearOverride

        public void clearOverride()
        Clear the collection of Override
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Contains all the Override messages which the user agreed to during Input. During the validation stage of a Foreign Exchange contract, the system may provide the user with a series of screen override messages to indicate an anomaly, for instance, that the exchange rate varies by more than the variation tolerance defined in the CURRENCY table. In the event that the user confirms the Override, the full text of the actual Override Message will be stored, for reference purposes only, in this multivalue field. For example, if the user inserts an 'abnormal' exchange rate the field corresponding to the exchange rate then when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'VARIANCE OF RATE EXCEEDS PERMITTED TOLERANCE' This will draw the user's attention to the rate entered, which may be a mistake and can then be corrected, or, on the other hand, it may be correct input and so the user confirms that this rate is really intended. A second example might be in respect of a contract done with a client who has a credit line established with the bank but where the maturity date of the intended Foreign Exchange contract goes beyond the credit line expiry date. In this case when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'LINE EXPIRES BEFORE TXN MATURITY' Once again the user's attention is drawn to the situation and either corrected or confirmed via a positive response to the Override Message. If, subsequently, the contract record is either fully displayed or printed, then all override messages will be present. Validation Rules: Internal field. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        nothing

      • clearPoBrReference

        public void clearPoBrReference()
        Clear the collection of PoBrReference
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.
        Parameters:
        Returns:
        nothing

      • clearPoReferenceTop

        public void clearPoReferenceTop()
        Clear the collection of PoReferenceTop
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.
        Parameters:
        Returns:
        nothing

      • clearStmtNo

        public void clearStmtNo()
        Clear the collection of StmtNo
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: A number generated automatically by the system which identifies either a statement entry or a category entry in respect of a contract. The system will automatically insert a number into this field and this number may refer to a statement entry or a category entry depending on the value contained in the corresponding multivalue fields. The following examples will illustrate the use of this field. Example 1: On the value date of a Foreign Exchange contract there will be an entry on the our account pay and the following type of number will be generated at this field: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1 The number automatically generated in Field 104.1 is unique to the contract in question and is built in the following way: 1. The first four digits '6737' indicate the number of days since the 1st of January 1968. In our example, it corresponds to the 11th of June 1986. 2. The next five digits '32684' indicate the number of seconds since midnight. In our example, it corresponds to an entry generated on line at 09:04:44 AM. 3. The last two digits '48' indicate the number of hundreds of seconds. The value assigned (again automatically) to field 154.2 identifies the number in 154.1 as a statement entry number. If the user wishes to call this statement entry record on to the screen the user will invoke the STMT.ENTRY Application and then type the following at 'AWAITING ID': 673732684.480001 where the suffix '0001' identifies it as the first statement entry (there may be more than one as the next example will illustrate). Example 2: A second example outlined here is similar to example 1 in that there is a statement entry on value date for both the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. The system handles this case as follows: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1-2 Once again field 154.1 contains the identification number automatically generated by the system while field 154.2 now contains two separate numbers signifying that there are in fact two separate statement entries, one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. If the user wishes to see either of these he must first of all invoke STMT.ENTRY followed by the desired function and then at 'AWAITING ID' type either: 673732684.480001 where the addition of the suffix '0001' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT PAY or 673732684.480002 where the addition of the suffix '0002' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT RECEIVE. Example 3: A third example might be that of a category entry generated at initiation of a contract where commission or charges have been debited to the customer and credited to a profit and loss category code. In this case the following entries are generated on the contract: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.3 STMT.NO ............ 1 Once again the standard type number is generated and inserted at field 154.1 Now, however, field 154.2 is replaced by Field 104.3 which now identifies the number in 154.1 as a category entry and not a statement entry. To call this category entry record onto the screen the user must now type: CATEG.ENTRY at 'AWAITING APPLICATION' followed by: 673732684.480001 at 'AWAITING ID'. Validation Rules: Internal multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        nothing

      • clearSwapRefNo

        public void clearSwapRefNo()
        Clear the collection of SwapRefNo
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This field links together all legs of a swap deal by holding the reference number of each deal. It is generated automatically by the system and no operator input is allowed. On Swap deals, the Foreign Exchange Application will keep on each leg all the reference numbers of the various transactions which are part of the swap deal. This will allow the user to see on any leg of the contract, all other transactions involved in the swap deal. Validation Rules: Standard Foreign Exchange reference number. System generated. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        nothing

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        nothing

        This field can be used only for Metal Trades. Validation Rules: 1-35 Alpha-numeric characters. Input mandatory for non ISDA type Agreements.

        nothing

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        LocalRefGroup -

      • getAccountOfficer

        public TField getAccountOfficer()
        Returns the AccountOfficer

        Field description: Identifies the account officer responsible for the relationship with the CPARTY. This information will be used by the Management Information System (MIS) for the determination of the Customer Profitability Analysis. This field has been provided to enable the user to override at transaction level the CPARTY default account officer defined in the CUSTOMER file. Validation Rules: 1-4 digit numeric field. (Optional input; Default value = account officer specified on the CPARTY's customer file.) The Account Officer Code must appear on the DEPT.ACCT.OFFICER table.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The AccountOfficer

      • getAccountToCharge

        public TField getAccountToCharge()
        Returns the AccountToCharge

        Field description: Identifies the account that is to be debited for any charges or commission defined in the field CHARGE.CODE. An account number should be entered when charges or commissions are to be applied. Charges will be applied immediately at authorisation whatever the contract type. It is important to note that the currency of the ACCOUNT.TO.CHARGE must exist on the table (FT.CHARGE.TYPE or FT.COMMISSION.TYPE) referred to by the CHARGE.CODE. Whenever one of the amounts (AMOUNT.BOUGHT or AMOUNT.SOLD) is in the currency of the ACCOUNT.TO.CHARGE, this amount will be used to calculate the charge amount. If none of the amounts is in the currency of the ACCOUNT.TO.CHARGE, the AMOUNT.SOLD will be converted at the middle rate in the currency of the ACCOUNT.TO.CHARGE and the charges calculated on this converted amount. Validation Rules: Standard numeric account number or 3-10 type MNE (uppercase alphanumeric, or '.') character Account Mnemonic. (Optional input ; default value = None.) It must be a valid account number in the same company. If the customer of the account is not the same as the CPARTY, an override will be required. Input in this field is only allowed and will also be mandatory when a CHARGE.CODE is defined. The currency of the ACCOUNT.TO.CHARGE must exist on the CHARGE table.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The AccountToCharge

      • getActionType

        public TField getActionType()
        Returns the ActionType

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting information to a Trade Repository. Under the Regulatory Reporting to a Trade Repository, it is not only the initial trade that is reported but also the life cycle events of the Trade that follow. A change in the action type is indicative of an event on the contract and requires to be reported. Change in Action Types is allowed both manually and automatically. Specifies the ACTION.TYPE that is populated based on the event on trade Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed and for FW or SW type FX contracts or when SUB.DEAL.TYPE is not 'IN' Validation Rules: Allowed optional values are N,M,E,C,Z and O N denotes that the ACTION.TYPE is NEW. Value of 'N' is defaulted for a new contract. User is also allowed to change the status to N if the previous status is E. E denotes that the ACTION.TYPE is REVERSE or Correction. In case of wrongly entered UTI values or a Temporary UTI was used previously, the old UTI should be reported with ACTION.TYPE as 'E' for error reporting first and then change the Action Type to NEW after keying in the actual UTI. This way the previous reporting with temporary UTI is replaced by the one with final UTI. Action Type E is also used to undo the reporting of a particular transaction done which should not have been done reported at all in the first instance. M denotes that the ACTION.TYPE is MODIFIED.A modification to any Primary Economic Terms (PET) like a partial settlement made in case of FX trades. C denotes the termination of the contract before its final maturity date. ACTION.TYPE is updated with the value as 'C' when full contractual amount has been delivered before the final maturity date Z denotes Compression update. This means the trade being reported is generated out of a compression activity. O denotes OTHER types. When OTHER is used, additional information as to what OTHER mean should be mentioned separately.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The ActionType

      • getAddlInfoMetal

        public List<TField> getAddlInfoMetal()
        Returns the collection of AddlInfoMetal

        Field description: This field is used to input additional information which corresponds to the Tag 72 on MT600,604,605 swift messages. Validation Rules: Multi-value field. 1-35 Alpha-numeric characters User can enter information in this field only if any of the fields among DELIVERY.DETAILS,METAL.TYPE and QUANTITY contains 'OTH'/'OTHR' Number of multi-values allowed on this field is based on the no of occurrence of 'OTH' value among the fields DELIVERY.DETAILS,METAL.TYPE and QUANTITY.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        List<TField> -

Validation Rules: Multi-value field. 1-35 Alpha-numeric characters User can enter information in this field only if any of the fields among DELIVERY.DETAILS,METAL.TYPE and QUANTITY contains 'OTH'/'OTHR' Number of multi-values allowed on this field is based on the no of occurrence of 'OTH' value among the fields DELIVERY.DETAILS,METAL.TYPE and QUANTITY.

        Parameters:
        idx - idx of the element to return
        Returns:
        TField -

      • getAgreementType

        public TField getAgreementType()
        Returns the AgreementType

        Field description:

        Defines the contract's agreement type. The same should have been defined on the FX.AGREEMENT.TYPE table . Eg ISDA ( ISDA master agreement ) etc .

        This field corresponds to tag 77H on MT600 and MT300 Swift messages.If the Agreement type is OTHER,it is mandatory to furnish additional information in the field Term And Conds in Forex Template which corresponds to tag 77D in MT600 Swift messages

        Validation Rules

        Must be a valid definition on the FX.AGREEMENT.TYPE file.ID of this contain either one of the below format.

        TYPE.

        TYPE/DATE//VERSION.

        User can input values for both metal and non metal trades.

        Input mandatory for metal trade since tag 77H of MT 600 is mandatory.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The AgreementType

      • getAmortisePosition

        public TField getAmortisePosition()
        Returns the AmortisePosition

        Field description: Currency position amortisation flag. For position amortisation to take place certain CATEGORY codes must be set up on FX.PARAMETERS and ACCOUNT.CLASS. The ACCOUNT.CLASS record FXCCYPOS must contain a category code to use in the reserve account numbers for the currencies involved. An internal account must be created using this code for the local currency. FX.PARAMETERS will require a product category for forex forward interest cover in the field CAT.CODE.FWD.INT. P&L codes for forward interest cover should be set in the following two fields. Validation Rules: Y, NO or BOTH. Defaults to NO. Must be NO if CAT.CODE.FWD.INT not specified on FX.PARAMETERS. If BOTH is selected then accrual entries are raised on LCY and FCY positions.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The AmortisePosition

      • getAmountBought

        public TField getAmountBought()
        Returns the AmountBought

        Field description: Contains the amount of the currency being purchased. If no value is entered, the amount will be calculated automatically by the system as explained in the Details. It is important to note that either the amount bought or amount sold must be entered. From this the other value can be calculated in the system's exchange rate routine. This routine can work in a number of ways. 1. If one amount and the exchange rate are entered, the routine calculates the other amount. 2. If both amounts are entered, the routine calculates the exchange rate. 3. If one amount , i.e buy or sell, and the Treasury rate are entered and Margin Percentage exists in the contract, the Spot/Forward rate so derived is used to calculate the other amount. 4. When both amounts and the exchange rate are entered, the correctness of the input is checked as follows: i) the 1st amount input is recalculated from the 2nd amount and the exchange rate. ii) the difference between the amount input and the recalculated amount is converted to local currency (using the mid-rate) and compared with the minimum and maximum conversion tolerances defined in the company record. iii) if the difference is not greater than the minimum tolerance, the input amount is accepted with no message. iv) if the difference is greater than the minimum tolerance but not greater than the maximum tolerance, an override message is displayed, allowing the input amount to be accepted or changed. v) if the difference is greater than the maximum tolerance, the amount input is replaced with the recalculated amount and an override message is displayed, allowing the recalculated amount to be accepted or changed. The currency of the deal will dictate the format of the amount. For example 1285.75 is a valid amount in US dollars but it is not acceptable in Japanese Yen as there is no smaller denomination (i.e. there are no decimal places). The number of decimal places is specified for each currency in the Currency table and the amount entered will be validated against this. To assist in entry, the operator may input T for Thousand and M for Million. Entering 10T, therefore, will result in 10,000.00 being displayed if the currency has been defined with two decimals. Validation Rules: Standard T24 amount validation. The actual format will depend on the number of decimal places in the currency being traded. If this field is left blank the system will calculate the amount bought based on the amount sold and the exchange rate used. The system expects either the amount bought or sold to be entered. The amount must be an acceptable format for the currency (e.g. USD 1,000.123 would not be acceptable as the US dollar will surely have been defined with two decimals on the currency table). The amount entered cannot be changed once the deal is authorised. Input for the non-base amount is not allowed for swap second leg when the Margin Percentage functionality Percentage is given to derive the contract rate.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The AmountBought

      • getAmountSold

        public TField getAmountSold()
        Returns the AmountSold

        Field description: Contains the amount of the currency being sold. If no value is entered, the amount will be calculated automatically by the system as explained in the Details. It is important to note that either the amount bought or amount sold must be entered. From this the other value can be calculated in the system's exchange rate routine. This routine can work in a number of ways: 1. If one amount and the exchange rate are entered, the routine calculates the other amount. 2. If both amounts are entered, the routine calculates the exchange rate. 3. If one amount , i.e buy or sell, and the Treasury rate are entered and Margin Percentage exists in the contract, the spot/Forward rate so derived is used to calculate the other amount. 4. If both amounts and the exchange rate have been entered by the operator, the routine validates the correctness of the input within the tolerance defined on the Company table. (see AMOUNT.BOUGHT). The currency of the deal will dictate the format of the amount. For example 1285.75 is a valid amount in US dollars but it is not acceptable in Japanese Yen as there is no smaller denomination (i.e. there is no decimal places). The number of decimal places is specified for each currency in the Currency table and the amount entered will be validated against this. To assist in entry, the operator may input T for Thousand and M for Million. Entering 10T, therefore, will result in 10,000.00 being displayed if the currency has been defined with two decimals. Validation Rules: Standard T24 amount validation. The actual format will depend on the number of decimal places in the currency being traded. If this field is left blank the system will calculate the amount sold based on the amount bought and the exchange rate used. The system expects either the amount bought or sold to be entered. The amount must be in an acceptable format for the currency (e.g. USD 1,000.123 would not be acceptable as the US dollar currency will surely have been defined with two decimals on the currency table). The amount entered cannot be changed once the deal is authorised. Input for the non-base amount is not allowed for swap second leg when the Margin percentage is given to derive the contract rate.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The AmountSold

      • getAmtBoughtOs

        public TField getAmtBoughtOs()
        Returns the AmtBoughtOs

        Field description: On a Nostro deal, the amount bought is defaulted into this field on Input. As Client deals are input, linked to the Nostro deal, the amount Bought on the client deal is reduced from this field. This field, therefore holds the outstanding amount Bought and is present only on Nostro deals. If a client deal causes the amount in this field to go negative, an override will be issued when validating the client deal. Validation Rules: This is a system maintained, NOINPUT field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The AmtBoughtOs

      • getAmtSoldOs

        public TField getAmtSoldOs()
        Returns the AmtSoldOs

        Field description: On a Nostro deal, the amount sold is defaulted into this field on Input. As Client deals are input, linked to the Nostro deal, the amount Sold on the client deal is reduced from this field. This field, therefore holds the outstanding amount Sold and is present only on Nostro deals. If a client deal causes the amount in this field to go negative, an override will be issued when validating the client deal. Validation Rules: This is a system maintained, NOINPUT field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The AmtSoldOs

      • getAuditDateTime

        Returns the AuditDateTime

        Returns:
        String - The AuditDateTime

        Returns the Authoriser

      • getAvailability

        public TField getAvailability()
        Returns the Availability

        Field description: This is a mandatory field if one or more of the currencies is a user defined precious metal. This user inputs the location where the metal is available for delivery Validation Rules: : Mandatory field 1-15 characters (uppercase alpha)

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The Availability

      • getBaseCcy

        public TField getBaseCcy()
        Returns the BaseCcy

        Field description: Identifies the base currency of the deal. It will be used to verify the exchange rate and to indicate the spread (if quoted) on customer deals. When the Base Currency is not specified and the transaction involves local Currency, the System will default to the local Currency provided that the Quotation code of the other Currency is NULL. If this is not the case (the Quotation code of the other Currency is not equal to null) then the other Currency will become the default. When the base Currency is not specified and the transaction involves two currencies where none is the Local Currency the system will prefer one with a RANK.BASE.CURRENCY field. If both currencies have values for this field then that with the lower value will be chosen as the base. If both are blank it will default to the Currency which yields a cross-rate greater than unity (One). Example 1: A UK User is processing a Foreign Exchange transaction involving Pounds Sterling and American Dollars. The base Currency which will be defaulted to in this case will be Pounds sterling because the Quotation code of the U.S. Dollar will be equal to null in the Currency table, i.e. in United Kingdom it is the Pound Sterling (local Currency) which is the Currency against which all foreign currencies are quoted. Example 2: A UK User is processing a Foreign Exchange transaction involving Swiss Francs and Deutsche Marks. The base Currency which will be defaulted in this case will be the Swiss Franc because it is the Currency which yields a cross-rate greater than unity. If a rate of 0.80 has been input, the User will be forced to indicate that the Deutsche Mark is the base Currency otherwise the Exchange Rate routine would refuse the rate input for incompatibility with the rates contained in the Currency table. The proper identification of the base Currency will allow the Exchange Rate routine to control the Exchange Rates input by the User against the Exchange Rate values contained in the Currency table. Validation Rules: 3 characters currency code (uppercase alpha or numeric) - Type SSS (Optional input. See details for default.) The currency entered must appear on the Currency table. The currency must be the same as either the currency bought or sold. Proper verification of the exchange rate will be performed by the system against the Exchange Rate values contained in the Currency table. Once authorised the Base currency cannot be amended.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BaseCcy

      • getBroker

        public TField getBroker()
        Returns the Broker

        Field description: If a deal has been arranged through a broker, this field should contain the code of the broker used. When no broker was involved in the foreign exchange deal, this field may also be used to specify the deal method. Examples of the methods that could be used are Telex, Reuters, Telephone, etc. The Broker field can either contain details of the broker used or the method that was used to make the deal such as: Telex Reuters Telephone Where 'BR' has been entered in the DEAL.SUB.TYPE, the operator must input a valid broker code in this field. The broker code may be entered either as a broker number or as a broker mnemonic. Once entered, the system checks that the broker exists on the broker table. Before a broker can be loaded on the broker table, the corresponding customer record must have been created on the customer file. Where Broker details are not required the operator may enter the deal method used. If entered, the two character code must appear on the FX.DEAL.METHOD table. Input in this field is not allowed for deal sub type 'IN'. Validation Rules: 1-6 numeric characters customer number or 3-10 characters customer mnemonic (uppercase alphanumeric or '.') - Type MNE or 2 characters deal method code. (Input is mandatory in this field for deal sub-type 'BR'; otherwise input is optional). Input not allowed for internal or negotiated deals. Input mandatory for Broker deals. If a broker code is entered, it must refer to a valid broker on the BROKER table. If entered as a deal method, it must refer to an element on the FX.DEAL.METHOD table.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The Broker

      • getBrokerage

        public TField getBrokerage()
        Returns the Brokerage

        Field description: This field is reserved for future expansion. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The Brokerage

      • getBrokerageAmount

        public TField getBrokerageAmount()
        Returns the BrokerageAmount

        Field description: Contains the amount of brokerage to be credit to the broker account specified in the broker currency defined above. If a brokerage amount has been entered above, then this field will identify the amount to be credited to the broker account. If no input is made a default will be calculated from the brokerage using the current mid market exchange rates. If the brokerage is specified in the same currency as the broker currency then the brokerage will be copied to this field. Validation Rules: Standard amount format for currency. (Optional input. Default calculated from the brokerage at mid market rates.) Input is not allowed in this field when the broker code has not been entered. Input not allowed in this field if no BROKERAGE, or BROKERAGE.CCY has been specified. The amount must be in a valid format for the brokerage currency. Input not allowed for Internal or Negotiated deals.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BrokerageAmount

      • getBrokerageCcy

        public TField getBrokerageCcy()
        Returns the BrokerageCcy

        Field description: Identifies the currency in which any brokerage defined in the next field is to be paid. The system allows brokerage to be settled in any currency providing it has been set up in the brokerage conditions on the BROKER table. The operator may enter the currency as an alpha code or it's numeric equivalent. Validation Rules: 3 characters - type SSS (uppercase alpha) or 1-3 numeric characters currency code. (Input only allowed when brokerage has been entered.) Default as the first currency in the BROKER record field CCY.FOR.PAYMENT. The currency must appear on the CURRENCY table. The currency must be specified on the BROKER table. Input is not allowed in this field when the broker has not been specified. Input not allowed for Internal or Negotiated deals. This field cannot be amended once the deal has been authorised.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BrokerageCcy

      • getBrokerageEquiv

        public TField getBrokerageEquiv()
        Returns the BrokerageEquiv

        Field description: The equivalent, in local currency of BROKERAGE.AMOUNT. The field only contains a value if brokerage in foreign currency has been entered for the deal. The amount recorded is the equivalent of BROKERAGE.AMOUNT converted at the mid-rate for the currency specified in BROKERAGE.CCY. This mid-rate is taken from the CURRENCY table at the time of input and will be used for all positions updates and accounting for the brokerage. Validation Rules: Standard amount format. System generated field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BrokerageEquiv

      • getBuildDate

        public String getBuildDate()
        Return the date/time of the creation of this class
        Parameters:
        Returns:
        String - the date/time of the creation of this class

      • getBuildVersion

        public String getBuildVersion()
        Return the compiler version used to create this class
        Parameters:
        Returns:
        String - the compiler vertion used to create this class

      • getBulkDeal

        public TField getBulkDeal()
        Returns the BulkDeal

        Field description: Defines whether the deal being entered is a Bulk (Nostro) deal. If set to 'Y', the deal being entered is a 'Nostro' deal. In this case when the contract is validated the AMOUNT.BOUGHT will be defaulted into the field AMT.BOUGHT.OS and the AMOUNT.SOLD will be defaulted into the field AMT.SOLD.OS. Validation Rules: Only 'Y' or Null will be accepted in this field. Can be 'Y' or Null. Both this field and the following field BULK.REFERENCE cannot be entered on the same contract.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BulkDeal

      • getBulkReference

        public TField getBulkReference()
        Returns the BulkReference

        Field description: On a 'Client' deal, this field holds the Deal Reference of the Bulk (Nostro) deal. The deal ID entered here will be used to check if the deal actually exists on the FOREX live file and that it is defined as a Bulk deal. If this field is entered, the Bulk reference will remain in memory until the FOREX application is exited. Once the Bulk reference exists in memory, typing a [Return] in this field, will default the information from the Nostro deal into this deal. The fields that have to be defaulted are defined in FX.PARAMETERS. Validation Rules: Standard FOREX deal format. The deal entered here must be an authorised, Bulk deal. Cannot be input if the previous field BULK.DEAL has been defined as 'Y'.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BulkReference

      • getBuyAccTdateF

        public TField getBuyAccTdateF()
        Returns the BuyAccTdateF

        Field description: Contains the foreign currency amount of the profit or loss accrued to-date on the 'Swap' or 'Forward' contract where the revaluation type 'IN' or 'IH' has been specified. This field will be increased daily by the amount specified in the daily accrual foreign currency table. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Interest revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.BUY, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in foreign currency) generated by the AMOUNT.BOUGHT at the INT.RATE.BUY. This field will then be incremented each day by the value of the daily (foreign currency) amount. In the case of Forward contracts done under the interest/hedged revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.BUY, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in foreign currency) generated by the NOTIONAL.AMT.BUY at the INT.RATE.BUY. This field will then be incremented each day by the value of the daily (foreign currency) amount. Example: Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,5773% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the amount bought, i.e. 1,000,000.00 x 12 x 1 ----------------------- = USD 333.33 36000 which, converted at the middle rate of 1.50, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 222.22. Consequently the value of this field will be USD 333.33 after the first day, then USD 666.66, etc. to USD 61,666.67 on the maturity date. Note: ---- 1. Under the Straight Line revaluation Method, this field will not be activated. 2. More information on the Straight Line and Interest revaluation method can be found in the Help Text for REVALUATION.TYPE. 3. The following rules will be followed for the conversion of the foreign currency accrual amount to its local currency equivalent: o When the contract involves local currency, it will be converted at the contract FORWARD.RATE. o When the contract does not involve the local currency, the BASE currency accrual amount will be converted at the CURRENCY table middle rate and the non-base accrual amount at the contract FORWARD.RATE and the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BuyAccTdateF

      • getBuyAccTdateL

        public TField getBuyAccTdateL()
        Returns the BuyAccTdateL

        Field description: Contains the local currency amount of the profit or loss accrued to-date on the 'Swap' or 'Forward' contracts when the revaluation type 'SL', 'IN' or 'IH' has been specified. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Straight Line revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the apparent exchange PROFIT generated by the forward nature of the transaction. This apparent exchange profit expressed in local currency (i.e. the difference between BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SELL.LCY.EQUIV) will be spread over the period of the contract to provide a per dium accrual amount in local currency. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Interest revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.BUY, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in local currency) generated by the AMOUNT.BOUGHT at the INT.RATE.BUY. In the case of Forward contracts done under the Interest/hedged revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT RATE BUY, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in local currency) generated by the NOTIONAL.BUY.AMT at the INT.RATE.BUY. Under the straight-line and interest methods of revaluation, this figure will normally be incremented each day by the value of the daily (local currency) amount in BUY.DAILY.ACC.L. It is, however, subject to an adjustment (on a rolling basis) to ensure that the entire net interest amount booked over the period of the accruals matches exactly the difference in BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV. Under the interest/hedged method of revaluation, the figure is the total of the local equivalents of accruals which have been booked to date in foreign currency. The local equivalent value of each of these daily accruals is calculated on the basis of the prevailing spot rate at the time. Examples: 1. Straight Line revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM (the Spot rate being 2.20) The apparent profit, i.e. DEM 50,000.00 will be accrued daily during the 6 month period (185 days in our example) and will generate a daily accrual of DEM 50,000.00 : 185 = DEM 270.27 which, converted at 3.30, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 81.90. Consequently, the value of this field will be GBP 81.90 after the first day, then GBP 163.80 etc. to GBP 15,151.51 (i.e. DEM 50,000.00) on the maturity date. 2. Interest revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,5773% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the amount bought, i.e. 1,000,000.00 x 12 x 1 ----------------------- = USD 333.33 36000 which, converted at the rate of 1.50, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 222.22. Consequently the value of this field will be GBP 222.22 after the first day, then GBP 444.44 etc. to GBP 41,111.11 on the maturity date. Notes: ----- 1. Under the Straight Line revaluation Method, this field will only be activated when the exchange contract has been done with a profit, i.e. the SELL.LCY.EQUIV is smaller (in absolute value) than the BUY.LCY.EQUIV. 2. Under the Interest revaluation method, the difference between the value generated in this field and the value generated in the field SEL.DAILY.ACC.L will correspond exactly to the daily accrual generated under the Straight Line revaluation method. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BuyAccTdateL

      • getBuyDailyAccF

        public TField getBuyDailyAccF()
        Returns the BuyDailyAccF

        Field description: Contains the daily foreign currency amount which is to be accrued on those 'Swap' or 'Forward' contracts where the revaluation type 'IN' or 'IH' has been specified. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Interest revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.BUY, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in foreign currency) generated by the AMOUNT.BOUGHT at the INT.RATE.BUY. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Interest/hedged revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.BUY, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in foreign currency) generated by the NOTIONAL.BUY.AMT at the INT.RATE.BUY. Examples: 1. Interest revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,5773% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the amount bought, i.e. 1,000,000.00 x 12 x 1 ----------------------- = USD 333.33 36000 which, converted at the middle rate of 1.50, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 222.22. The USD amount of 333.33 will then be recorded in this field. 2. Interest/hedged revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,1441% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the notional principal underlying the amount bought, i.e. 943,835.33 x 12 x 1 ------------------- = 310.30 3600 which, converted at the rate of 1.50, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 206.87. The USD amount of 310.30 will then be recorded in this field. Note: ---- 1. Under the Straight Line revaluation Method, this field will not be activated. 2. More information on the Straight Line and Interest revaluation method can be found in the Help Text for REVALUATION.TYPE. 3. The following rules will be followed for the conversion of the foreign currency accrual amount to its local currency equivalent: o When the contract involves local currency, it will be converted at the contract FORWARD.RATE. o When the contract does not involve the local currency, the BASE currency accrual amount will be converted at the CURRENCY table middle rate and the non-base accrual amount at the contract FORWARD.RATE and the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BuyDailyAccF

      • getBuyDailyAccL

        public TField getBuyDailyAccL()
        Returns the BuyDailyAccL

        Field description: Contains the daily local currency amount which is to be accrued on those 'Swap' or 'Forward' contracts where the revaluation type 'SL', 'IN' or 'IH' has been specified. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Straight Line revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the apparent exchange PROFIT generated by the forward nature of the transaction. This apparent exchange PROFIT expressed in local currency (i.e. the difference between BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SELL.LCY.EQUIV) will be spread over the period of the contract to provide a per dium accrual amount in local currency. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Interest revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.BUY, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in local currency) generated by the AMOUNT.BOUGHT at the INT.RATE.BUY. In the case of Forward contracts done under the Interest/hedged revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.BUY, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in local currency) generated by the NOTIONAL.BUY.AMT at the INT.RATE.BUY. Under the straight-line and interest methods of revaluation, this figure will normally be exactly the local equivalent amount at which each day's interest accrual is booked. It is, however, subject to an adjustment (on a rolling basis) to ensure that the entire net interest amount booked over the period of the accruals matches exactly the difference in BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV. Under the interest/hedged method of revaluation, the figure is for information purposes only. The accruals will actually be booked in foreign currency against a local equivalent at the prevailing spot rate. Examples: 1. Straight Line revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6 MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM (the Spot rate being 2.20). The apparent profit, i.e. DEM 50,000.00 will be accrued daily during the 6 month period (185 days in our example) and will generate a daily accrual of DEM 50,000.00 : 185 = DEM 270.27 which, converted at the rate of 3.30, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 81.90. This amount will then be recorded in this field. 2. Interest revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,5773% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the amount bought, i.e. 1,000,000.00 x 12 x 1 ----------------------- = USD 333.33 3600 which, converted at the rate of 1.50, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 222.22. This amount will then be recorded in this field. 3. Interest/hedged revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,1441% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the notional principal underlying the amount bought, i.e. 943,835.33 x 12 x 1 ------------------- = 310.30 3600 which, converted at the rate of 1.50, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 206.87. This amount will then be recorded in this field. Notes: ----- 1. Under the Straight Line revaluation Method, this field will only be activated when the exchange contract has been done with a profit, i.e. the SELL.LCY.EQUIV is smaller (in absolute value) than the BUY.LCY.EQUIV. 2. Under the Interest revaluation method, the difference between the value generated in this field and the value generated in the field SEL.DAILY.ACC.L will correspond exactly to the daily accrual generated under the Straight Line revaluation method. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BuyDailyAccL

      • getBuyLcyEquiv

        public TField getBuyLcyEquiv()
        Returns the BuyLcyEquiv

        Field description: Contains the local currency equivalent of the currency being purchased. The field will be calculated by the system and no operator input will be allowed. This local currency equivalent will be used when updating the currency position after successful validation. When Foreign Exchange deals are first entered into the foreign currency position, the local currency equivalent for both the BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV depends on the revaluation method specified in the corresponding contract. The following rules will be adhered to for each one of the revaluation methods below: REBATE METHOD The following rules will be followed: a) When the contract involves local currency It is always the local currency amount (AMOUNT.BOUGHT or AMOUNT.SOLD) which will be used to generate the local currency value in BOTH fields BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV. b) When the contract does not involve local currency The BASE amount of the contract will beconverted at contract FORWARD.RATE and the forward rate of the other currency (non base currency) to generate the local currency value in BOTH fields BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV. If for example: SPOT GBP/DEM = 3,30 SPOT GBP/USD = 1,50 FWD 3 MONTH GBP/USD = 1,48 FWD 3 MONTH GBP/DEM = 3,24 the following local currency equivalents will be calculated by the system for the next deals: Deal 1 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 1.48 (Spot Rate) :(1.50) Currency & Amount Sold : GBP 675,675.68 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 01 Revaluation Type : RB SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-675,675.68 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 675,675.68 Deal 2 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 2.18 (Spot Rate) :(2.20) Currency & Amount Sold : DEM 2,180,000.00 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 02 Revaluation Type : RB SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-672,839.51 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 672,839.51 STRAIGHT LINE METHOD The following rules will be followed: a) When the contract involves local currency - The local currency amount of the contract will be kept to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV, i.e: if AMOUNT.BOUGHT = Local currency, then AMOUNT.BOUGHT = BUY.LCY.EQUIV if AMOUNT.SOLD = Local currency, then AMOUNT.SOLD = SEL.LCY.EQUIV - The foreign currency amount of the contract will be converted at at the contract SPOT.RATE to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. b) When the contract does not involve local currency - The BASE amount of the contract will be converted at the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. - The other foreign currency amount of the contract will be converted at the contract SPOT.RATE and the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. If for example: SPOT GBP/DEM = 3,30 SPOT GBP/USD = 1,50 the following local currency equivalents will be calculated by the system for the next deals: Deal 1 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 1.48 (Spot Rate) :(1.50) Currency & Amount Sold : GBP 675,675.68 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 01 Revaluation Type : SL SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 675,675.68 Deal 2 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 2.18 (Spot Rate) :(2.20) Currency & Amount Sold : DEM 2,180,000.00 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 02 BASE Currency : USD Revaluation Type : SL SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 660,606.06 INTEREST & INTEREST/HEDGED METHODS The same rules as the ones defined for the Straight Line method wiill be followed, i.e: a) When the contract involves local currency - The local currency amount of the contract will be kept to generate the lcoal currency value in the corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SELL.LCY.EQUIV, i.e: if AMOUNT.BOUGHT = Local currency, then AMOUNT.BOUGHT = BUY.LCY.EQUIV if AMOUNT.SOLD = Local currency, then AMOUNT.SOLD = SEL.LCY.EQUIV - The foreign currency amount of the contract will be converted at the contract SPOT.RATE to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. b) When the contract does not involve local currency - the BASE amount of the contract will be converted at the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. - The other foreign currency amount of the contract will be converted at the contract SPOT.RATE and the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. If for example: SPOT GBP/DEM = 3,30 SPOT GBP/USD = 1,50 the following local currency equivalents will be calculated by the system for the next deals: Deal 1 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 1.48 (Spot Rate) :(1.50) Currency & Amount Sold : GBP 675,675.68 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 01 Revaluation Type : IN Interest rate buy : 6.964504654 Interest rate sell : 9.75 SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 675,675.68 Deal 2 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 2.18 (Spot Rate) :(2.20) Currency & Amount Sold : DEM 2,180,000.00 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 02 BASE Currency : USD Revaluation Type : IN Interest rate buy : 6.00 Interest rate sell : 4.191863385 SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 660,606.06 SPOT CONTRACTS The following rules will be followed: a) Where either the actual amount bought or amount sold happens to be in the local currency of the country (Deal 1), this amount will be adopted as the local currency equivalent for the other currency so that the fields BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV on the main Foreign Exchange contract will contain this same value. It is also this local currency value which will be used to update the Foreign Exchange position once the deal has been successfully validated. b) Where the local currency is neither the currency bought nor the currency sold (Deal 2), the system will calculate the local currency equivalent of the BASE currency/amount and apply it to both currencies of the contract so that fields BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV on the main Foreign Exchange contract will also contain the same value. To calculate this local currency equivalent of the BASE amount, the system will take the existing middle rate of the base currency as defined on the CURRENCY table. We have supposed here that on the CURRENCY table the middle rate GBP/USD is equal to 1,50. Like in the previous case it is also this local currency equivalent which will be used to update the Foreign Exchange position once the deal has been successfully validated. If for example: SPOT GBP/DEM = 3,30 SPOT GBP/USD = 1,50 the following local currency equivalents will be calculated by the system for the next deals: Deal 1 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 1.5000 Currency & Amount Sold : GBP 666,666.67 Value Date : SPOT Dealer Desk : 01 SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 666,666.67 Deal 2 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 2,2000 Currency & Amount Sold : DEM 2,200,000.00 Value Date : SPOT Dealer Desk : 02 BASE Currency : USD SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 666,666.67 Validation Rules: System Generated. Standard Amount Format preceded with the '-' sign.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The BuyLcyEquiv

      • getCategoryCode

        public TField getCategoryCode()
        Returns the CategoryCode

        Field description: Contains the category code to which the deal will be accounted. This information will be used for MIS reporting and will identify the product being processed. Note: 1. A default category code may be specified for each deal type on the FX.TRANSACTION.TYPE file. 2. The product category code range for Foreign Exchange is 20000-20999. Validation Rules: 5 numeric digits in range 20000-20999. (Optional input; default value see note below.) The category code must be defined on the CATEGORY table. The category code must relate to the FX application.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The CategoryCode

      • getChargeCode

        idx - index of the element to return
