      • getMarginPerc

        public TField getMarginPerc()
        Returns the MarginPerc

        Field description: The value in this field is either defaulted from FX.GROUP.CONDITION ( if the field CUS.MARGIN.DEFAULT in FX.PARAMETER is set to Yes) or User can input a value or override the one defaulted by the system, provided there exists a value in the field "TREASURY.RATE". Validation Rules: No Change field. System raises a validation error when, Both amount bought and sold are given. Contract rate is given with or without amount bought or sold or both.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The MarginPerc

      • getMarginPips

        public TField getMarginPips()
        Returns the MarginPips

        Field description: Using the values in the fields- Margin.Perc and Treasury. Rate , system calculates the margin amount in terms of PIPS that needs to be added or subtracted to the Treasury Rate to arrive at the Contract/Customer Rate , which then will be used to calculate the Amount bought or sold depending what is inputted by the User. The value can be recalculated by modifying the Margin Percentage given, in case the User needs to. Formula to calculate is = Treasury Rate x Margin Percentage Validation Rules: Noinput field. 1-15 type R Up to 8 integer and 9 decimal

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The MarginPips

      • getMetalType

        public TField getMetalType()
        Returns the MetalType

        Field description:

        This is mandatory field if one or more of the currencies is a user defined precious metal. This is a user input field denoting the variety of the metal required by the client, out of the following available options:

        GOLD

        SILV

        PLAT

        PALL

        RODH

        RUTH

        OSMI

        IRID

        Validation Rules :

        Mandatory field.

        When GOLD is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should not be GOZ or TOZ.

        When Silver/Palladium/Platinum is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should be only GOZ.

        4 characters (uppercase alpha).

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The MetalType

      • getMktgExchAdj

        public TField getMktgExchAdj()
        Returns the MktgExchAdj

        Field description: Identifies the profit adjustment that will be added to the MKTG.EXCH.PROFIT. Any profit relating to the Marketing area is credited to the Profit and Loss category code '53006' with the Profit Centre code of the Counterparty (CUSTOMER). All exchange profit on revaluation will accrue to the Treasury area.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The MktgExchAdj

      • getMktgExchProfit

        public TField getMktgExchProfit()
        Returns the MktgExchProfit

        Field description: Identifies the local currency exchange profit amount taken on the Foreign Exchange transaction which has been allocated to the Marketing Unit. When the CPARTY of the Foreign Exchange transaction has not been defined as a Treasury Customer, the allocation of exchange earnings is made automatically between Treasury and Marketing units at the time of the transaction. Any profit relating to the Marketing area (i.e. Contract rate - Treasury rate) is credited to the Profit and Loss category code '53006' with the Profit Center code of the CPARTY. The offset will be done in the same Profit and Loss Category code with the Profit Centre code of the corresponding Dealer Desk. All exchange profit on revaluation will therefore accrue to the Treasury area. Calculation: 1. Get Treasury rate 2. Calculate non base amount using base amount and Treasury rate. 3. Profit is the difference between calculated non base amount and contract non base amount. 4. Convert difference amount to local currency at middle rate if necessary. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The MktgExchProfit

      • getNegotiatedRefNo

        public TField getNegotiatedRefNo()
        Returns the NegotiatedRefNo

        Field description: Input not allowed unless deal sub type is 'NE', and this sub-type had been made as invalid.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The NegotiatedRefNo

      • getNettingStatus

        public TField getNettingStatus()
        Returns the NettingStatus

        Field description: Indicates that the contract has been elected for settlement by a netted payment. Entering N into this field will ensure that the contract will be excluded from any valid net settlement. Validation Rules: Y or N. (Optional input, Default = Nul, will be elected for settlement by a netted payment if a valid NETTING.AGREEMENT is present for the contract customer) The counterparty for this contract must have a valid netting agreement to enter 'Y'.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The NettingStatus

      • getNonStndFlag

        public TField getNonStndFlag()
        Returns the NonStndFlag

        Field description: An optional field to indicate if the contract is a standard or non standard contract. Useful for OC reporting. Validation Rules: Allowed optional values are Y Indicates that the contract is a non standard contract N Indicates that the contract is a standard contract

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The NonStndFlag

      • getNotes

        public TField getNotes(int idx)
        Returns the Notes at the specified position in this collection.

        Field description: This element allows the user to record any special information or free form narrative. This narrative is for information only and will not be printed on the confirmation sent to the customer. These notes are for the benefit of the back/front office department and as such will not be output on the confirmation sent to the CPARTY. Validation Rules: 1-4 lines with up to 35 characters in each line.

        Parameters:
        idx - idx of the element to return
        Returns:
        TField -

      • getNotes

        public List<TField> getNotes()
        Returns the collection of Notes

        Field description: This element allows the user to record any special information or free form narrative. This narrative is for information only and will not be printed on the confirmation sent to the customer. These notes are for the benefit of the back/front office department and as such will not be output on the confirmation sent to the CPARTY. Validation Rules: 1-4 lines with up to 35 characters in each line.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        List<TField> -

      • getNotionalBuyAmt

        public TField getNotionalBuyAmt()
        Returns the NotionalBuyAmt

        Field description: The notional principal amount underlying the contract amount bought. Revaluation method 'IH' only. This field is only used when the interest/hedged revaluation method has been selected for a forward contract (REVALUATION.TYPE, is 'IH'). The value which the system places in this field represents a 'notional' principal amount. This is the amount which, at the given interest rate (INT.RATE.BUY) over the lifetime of the deal, will yield the contract amount (AMOUNT.BOUGHT). This notional amount is used to update currency position records for the buy side of the deal. This contrasts with all other revaluation methods, under which the full contract amount is placed in the forward exchange position. The interest element of the contract amount is amortised and positioned seperately over the life of the deal. The system calculates the NOTIONAL.BUY.AMT according to the following formula: NA = ( A / 100 + ( IR * STV / IDB ) ) * 100 where: NA = notional (buy) amount A = amount (bought) IR = interest rate (currency bought) STV = spot-to-value number of days (currency bought) IDB = interest day basis (currency bought) This figure is, in turn, used to calculate the interest element of the AMOUNT.BOUGHT (by subtraction). Validation Rules: Standard amount format. System generated field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The NotionalBuyAmt

      • getNotionalSellAmt

        public TField getNotionalSellAmt()
        Returns the NotionalSellAmt

        Field description: The notional principal amount underlying the contract amount sold. Revaluation method 'IH' only. This field is only used when the interest/hedged revaluation method has been selected for a forward contract (REVALUATION.TYPE, is 'IH'). The value which the system places in this field represents a 'notional' principal amount. This is the amount which, at the given interest rate (INT.RATE.SELL) over the lifetime of the deal, will yield the contract amount (AMOUNT.SOLD). This notional amount is used to update currency position records for the sell side of the deal. This contrasts with all other revaluation methods, under which the full contract amount is placed in the forward exchange position. The interest element of the contract amount is amortised and positioned seperately over the life of the deal. The system calculates the NOTIONAL.SELL.AMT according to the following formula: NA = ( A / 100 + ( IR * STV / IDB ) ) * 100 where: NA = notional (sell) amount A = amount (sold) IR = interest rate (currency sold) STV = spot-to-value number of days (currency sold) IDB = interest day basis (currency sold) This figure is, in turn, used to calculate the interest element of the AMOUNT.SOLD (by subtraction). Validation Rules: Standard amount format. System generated field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The NotionalSellAmt

      • getOldIntRateCalc

        public TField getOldIntRateCalc()
        Returns the OldIntRateCalc

        Field description: The interest rates calculated for 'IN' - Interest revaluation method can use either the old formula as in the previous versions of T24 or use the new formula that is used by the 'IH' - Interest hedge method. This can be controlled by this parameter OLD.INT.RATE.CALC provided on the FOREX application. The system will use the new formula by default and in order to use the old formula the user will have to input a 'YES' into this field. Validation Rules: Optional input. Allowed Values are Null or 'Y'es.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The OldIntRateCalc

      • getOptionAmount

        public TField getOptionAmount()
        Returns the OptionAmount

        Field description: The amount of the option contract in the OPTION currency. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field and defaulted at input time if the option currency has been defined.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The OptionAmount

      • getOptionCurrency

        public TField getOptionCurrency()
        Returns the OptionCurrency

        Field description: The currency considered to be the option currency. Validation Rules: Must be equal to the CURRENCY.BOUGHT or the CURRENCY.SOLD No change field Optional Input excepting if OPTION.TYPE is 'MULTI.RATE'

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The OptionCurrency

      • getOptionDate

        public TField getOptionDate()
        Returns the OptionDate

        Field description: Contains the date starting from which partial or total delivery may start for option deals. Most forward contracts have a specific value date. However, commercial customers are not always sure exactly when money is to be received or paid. In these cases the customer may wish to enter into forward contracts allowing for an option period. As an example, UK Ltd sells goods to USA Inc. and expects USD 100,000 in return. In practice UK Ltd knows that USA Inc. takes between 4 and 6 weeks to pay. To enable them to establish how much is to be received, UK Ltd will enter into a 6 week forward contract with an option to settle in 4 weeks time. The bank will quote the rate which is most favourable to them during the option period. Often, when an option deal is set up, the customer will take his option in separate parts. The Foreign Exchange Application allows the user to liquidate option deals in various transactions during the option period i.e. any number of partial deliveries will be allowed during the option period. For further details see separate FOREX section of helptext, 'Option Contracts'. Notes: i) Accruals on Forward contracts using the Straight Line or Interest revaluation method will be calculated from the SPOT.DATE to this date. ii) As soon as the first delivery has taken place during the option period, reversal of the contract will no longer be allowed. Validation Rules: Any date format accepted by T24. The option date must not be later than the value date. The option date must be later than the deal date. The option date must be later than today's date. The option date must be later than the Spot date as defined on the FX.PARAMETERS table on the field SPOT.INTERNAL. The option date must be a business day for the currency involved. Option dates are not allowed for Spot or Swap deals. Option dates are not allowed for Internal or Negotiated deals. Option dates are not allowed when revaluation type is 'IH' (interest/hedged). This field cannot be amended after authorisation.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The OptionDate

      • getOptionOsAmt

        public TField getOptionOsAmt()
        Returns the OptionOsAmt

        Field description: The remaining amount of the deal in the OPTION currency. This amount is the option amount still to taken down. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field. Defaulted from the BUY or SELL amount initially and recalculated every time there is a take-down.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The OptionOsAmt

        Returns the OsDelBuyAmt

        Field description: This amount corresponds to the outstanding amount in the bought currency that is still available for delivery. In case of Multi-Option Contracts, where the Option Currency is the Currency Sold, this amount is only notional. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The OsDelBuyAmt

      • getOsDelSellAmt

        Returns the OsDelSellAmt

        Field description: This amount corresponds to the outstanding amount in the sold currency that is still available for delivery. In case of Multi-Option Contracts, where the Option Currency is the Currency Bought, this amount is only notional. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The OsDelSellAmt

      • getOsLcyEquivAmt

        public TField getOsLcyEquivAmt()
        Returns the OsLcyEquivAmt

        Field description: The local equivalent amount of the outstanding amount. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field. If a local currency is involved in the deal then this amount will be equal to the outstanding amount in the local currency. If both currencies involved are foreign currencies then this amount will be the local equivalent of the outstanding amount in the base currency.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The OsLcyEquivAmt

      • getOsLstLimBuyEop

        public TField getOsLstLimBuyEop()
        Returns the OsLstLimBuyEop

        Field description: This field holds the last value date with which the outstanding unused amount was updated in LIMITS. The field is used for the internal workings of LIMITS. Validation Rules: Automatically updated by the system. This is a NOINPUT field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The OsLstLimBuyEop

        TField - The OsLstLimSelEop

        List<OurAccountPayClass> -

      • getOverride

        public List<TField> getOverride()
        Returns the collection of Override

        Field description: Contains all the Override messages which the user agreed to during Input. During the validation stage of a Foreign Exchange contract, the system may provide the user with a series of screen override messages to indicate an anomaly, for instance, that the exchange rate varies by more than the variation tolerance defined in the CURRENCY table. In the event that the user confirms the Override, the full text of the actual Override Message will be stored, for reference purposes only, in this multivalue field. For example, if the user inserts an 'abnormal' exchange rate the field corresponding to the exchange rate then when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'VARIANCE OF RATE EXCEEDS PERMITTED TOLERANCE' This will draw the user's attention to the rate entered, which may be a mistake and can then be corrected, or, on the other hand, it may be correct input and so the user confirms that this rate is really intended. A second example might be in respect of a contract done with a client who has a credit line established with the bank but where the maturity date of the intended Foreign Exchange contract goes beyond the credit line expiry date. In this case when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'LINE EXPIRES BEFORE TXN MATURITY' Once again the user's attention is drawn to the situation and either corrected or confirmed via a positive response to the Override Message. If, subsequently, the contract record is either fully displayed or printed, then all override messages will be present. Validation Rules: Internal field. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        List<TField> -

      • getOverride

        public TField getOverride(int idx)
        Returns the Override at the specified position in this collection.

        Field description: Contains all the Override messages which the user agreed to during Input. During the validation stage of a Foreign Exchange contract, the system may provide the user with a series of screen override messages to indicate an anomaly, for instance, that the exchange rate varies by more than the variation tolerance defined in the CURRENCY table. In the event that the user confirms the Override, the full text of the actual Override Message will be stored, for reference purposes only, in this multivalue field. For example, if the user inserts an 'abnormal' exchange rate the field corresponding to the exchange rate then when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'VARIANCE OF RATE EXCEEDS PERMITTED TOLERANCE' This will draw the user's attention to the rate entered, which may be a mistake and can then be corrected, or, on the other hand, it may be correct input and so the user confirms that this rate is really intended. A second example might be in respect of a contract done with a client who has a credit line established with the bank but where the maturity date of the intended Foreign Exchange contract goes beyond the credit line expiry date. In this case when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'LINE EXPIRES BEFORE TXN MATURITY' Once again the user's attention is drawn to the situation and either corrected or confirmed via a positive response to the Override Message. If, subsequently, the contract record is either fully displayed or printed, then all override messages will be present. Validation Rules: Internal field. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        idx - idx of the element to return
        Returns:
        TField -

      • getPortfolioNumber

        public TField getPortfolioNumber()

        Field description: Identifies the customer portfolio number to which this FX deal will be associated with. This will be used for the portfolio valuation for that CPARTY. No input will result in this deal to be excluded from the portfolio valuation. Validation Rules: Up to 3 characters numeric. (Optional input)

        Parameters:

        TField - The PortfolioNumber

      • getPositionTypeBuy

        public TField getPositionTypeBuy()
        Returns the PositionTypeBuy

        Field description: Identifies the position type applicable to the foreign exchange transaction. This facility is not used at present. Typically any bank will maintain a 'TRADING' position which will reflect the net position of all dealing and back office activity. On the other side, the management of the bank could also decide, from time to time, to take a position outside the normal trading activity and which consequently will not be included in the day to day trading activity and position but instead in a separate position which will generally be called 'Management' position. This position will then be under the exclusive control of the management itself and will only consist of a very small number of foreign exchange deals (1 or 2). For the dealing room trader this management position will be transparent as it is normally outside his area of responsibility. Any foreign exchange deal where the position type 'Management' has been indicated, must be classified as internal and will update at the same time and in the opposite sense the Management position and the Trading position. The foreign exchange dealer will then make a second deal in the market to cover his own trading position. Only the Management position will then exist at this stage. When management decides to liquidate or undo this position, the reverse operation will take place. Before a type can be entered it must first be created on the FX Pos Type table. Example: Let us suppose that the management believes that the U.S. dollar will go down against the Deutsche Mark in the near future and that, for this reason, decides to sell one month forward 10 million dollars against Deutsche Mark. The following deals will then be created: 1) Internal deal between trader and management. The trader will buy dollars from management and sell Deutsche Mark to management which consequently will be short in dollars and long in Deutsche Marks. To keep the cost of the trading position intact, the exchange rate applicable to this transaction will normally be the rate agreed in the next deal (external deal). 2) The trader, to keep intact his trading position will make an opposite contract in the market for the same amount, rate and maturity date. The following position will then exist across the books of the bank: Trading Position ---------------- DEM USD - = SELL to management + = BUY from management + = BUY from the market - = SELL in the market _______________________ _______________________ SQUARE POSITION SQUARE POSITION Management Position ------------------- DEM USD + = BUY from trader - = SELL to trader ______________________ _____________________ Long in DEM Short in USD During the revaluation process, separate accounting entries will be generated for the Management position to strictly isolate any exchange Profit or Loss which will result from this position. Validation Rules: 2 characters. (Optional input; Default = TR for Trading) The code entered must appear on the FX.POS.TYPE table (see General Tables). Once authorised the field cannot be amended.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The PositionTypeBuy

      • getPositionTypeSell

        public TField getPositionTypeSell()
        Returns the PositionTypeSell

        Field description: This field, not used at present, is reserved for future use.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The PositionTypeSell

      • getPreUtiId1

        public TField getPreUtiId1()
        Returns the PreUtiId1

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting information to a Trade Repository. Denotes the Previous UNI.TRAN.ID value. When UNI.TRAN.ID is changed , it replaces the previous one and the previous one is moved into this field. Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed and for FW or SW type FX contracts or when SUB.DEAL.TYPE is not 'IN' Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field Can contain upto 52 alphanumeric characters

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The PreUtiId1

      • getPreUtiId2

        public TField getPreUtiId2()
        Returns the PreUtiId2

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting information to a Trade Repository. Denotes the Previous PRE.UTI.ID.1 value. When UNI.TRAN.ID is changed, it replaces the previous one and the previous value in PRE.UTI.ID.1 is moved into this field. Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed and for FW or SW type FX contracts or when SUB.DEAL.TYPE is not 'IN' Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field Can contain upto 52 alphanumeric characters

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The PreUtiId2

      • getPvpSettlement

        public TField getPvpSettlement()
        Returns the PvpSettlement

        Field description: Specifies whether the FX Contract is settled through Payment Versus Payment Settlement process and corresponds to the TAG 17I in MT300. PVP arrangement allows two currencies in an FX contract to be exchanged simultaneously on a central Settlement Platform to eliminate the Settlement Risk. To apply PVP, both the parties involved in the FX Contract need to have a pre-agreement with the CENTRAL SETTLEMENT PLATFORM. For Example, A USD/MYR FX deal requires both the parties to have an agreement to settle via HK Interbank Clearing Ltd. Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field Valid values are Y or N or Null N or NULL represents that the FX transaction is not PVP Y represents that the FX transaction is PVP Input not allowed for metal trade

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The PvpSettlement

      • getQuantity

        public TField getQuantity()
        Returns the Quantity

        Field description:

        This is a mandatory field if one or more of the currencies is a user defined precious metal. This is a user input field denoting the type of unit, in which the precious metal is to be transferred or delivered, out of the following options :

        FOZ

        GOZ

        GRM

        KLO

        LOT

        TAL

        TOL

        TOZ

        UNT

        Validation rules :

        Mandatory Field.

        When GOLD is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should not be GOZ or TOZ (GOZ and TOZ not supported for GOLD Metal type).

        When Silver/Palladium/Platinum is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should be only GOZ.

        3 alpha characters.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The Quantity

      • getRealiseFixPl

        public TField getRealiseFixPl()
        Returns the RealiseFixPl

        Field description: Specifies if the Profit and Loss from the deal is to be realised if the 2 currencies involved are linked to a fixed currency (i.e the EURO). Profit and Loss will be realised on the night before the fixed rate applies. There is no subsequent revaluation or accrual for the deal. When profit and loss is realised the existing unrealised P&L is backed out and is posted to the categories specified in REVALUATION.PARAMETER in the fields PRFT.FIX.CAT and LOSS.FIX.CAT, the exchange adjustment entries are posted to internal accounts of the category held in the fields PRFT.FIX.INT.CT and LOSS.FIX.INT.CT. For revaluation types SL, IN, IH and SF the remaining accrual is made on the night of realisation. Validation Rules: Optional input. Valid input of Y only. Input of Y only allowed if 2 currencies have a FIXED.CCY defined.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The RealiseFixPl

      • getRecordStatus

        public String getRecordStatus()
        Returns the RecordStatus
        Parameters:
        Returns:
        String - The RecordStatus

      • getReplacingDealNo

        public TField getReplacingDealNo()
        Returns the ReplacingDealNo

        Field description: Identifies a previous contract which has been reversed (due to an error) and which is replaced by this new transaction. This information is used with the narrative 'AMEND' on a SWIFT confirmation and is placed in Field 21 of an MT300. If it is not present on a new input, this indicates a 'new' MT300. Validation Rules: Up to 10 numeric characters. (Mandatory input when CORR.AMEND.MKR = 'A'; Optional input when CORR.AMEND.MKR = 'C'; Otherwise not allowed.) The deal number must exist on the history file in reverse status. Must be with the same CPARTY as an original deal.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The ReplacingDealNo

      • getReserved1

        public TField getReserved1()
        Returns the Reserved1

        Field description: Reserved for future use. Validation Rules: Noinput field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The Reserved1

      • getReserved10

        public TField getReserved10()
        Returns the Reserved10

        Field description: Reserved for future use Validation Rules: No Input Allowed

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The Reserved10

      • getRevaluationType

        public TField getRevaluationType()
        Returns the RevaluationType

        Field description: Identifies the revaluation methodto be used on forward contracts. The system handles five types of Revaluation: 'RB' = Rebate method 'SL' = Straight line 'IN' = Interest method 'IH' = Interest/hedged 'SF' = Straight line funding As it is the case for the spot contracts all open forward Foreign Exchange contracts are revalued on an individual deal basis using the current market rates. The forward rates used for the rebate revaluation are obtained from the FORWARD.RATE Table and where a rate is not available for a particular value date it is calculated by interpoltation, or the exchange rate of the nearest date will be selected according to the value defined on the REVALUATION.PARAMETER table. For the revaluation applicable to unmatured forward contracts, T24, allows the user to choose, at deal level, between five different methods. Rebate Method This is the most straightforward method as it is based (like the spot revaluation) on the cost or profit attributable to closing the position, i.e. to enter into a deal at today's rates to exactly cover each deal at its maturity (buy back approach). In the case of forward deals, the rate varies not only because of change in the market (supply and demand factors) but also because rates vary with time. For any given forward deal, as it ages, the rate to cover it, converges with the spot rate as it gets closer to maturity, until it will, eventually be covered at spot rate. Given a set of forward rates (FORWARD.RATES tables), the user can still choose between 3 methods to find the forward rate applicable to each forward contract, i.e: - Interpolation - Next available rate - Closest rate His choice will be indicated on the REVALUATION.PARAMETER table. The following explains how the interpolation works within FOREX. It is the only method where a rate will be found for each day. Interpolation of forward Exchange Rates The rates on the forward exchange rate table (FORWARD.RATES) can be defined for any period required by the user, (e.g. 1 week, 2 weeks, 15 days, 1 month, 2 months, 3 months etc..). The actual value date that the forward rates apply to are calculated as the: Reporting date + 2 working days + number of months. If this date is not a working day, then the next working day is used. When a date is required for a value date that falls between the dates of two rates on the table, then it is interpolated as follows: a) Number of days bbetween the dates of the two rates: TOTALDAYS = Latest Rate Date - Earliest Rate Date b) Difference between rates: DIFFERENCE = Latest Rate - Earliest Rate c) Rate of change per day: RATE OF CHANGE = DIFFERENCE ---------- TOTALDAYS d) The number of days to the required value date from the earliest date is multiplied by the rate of change, then the result is added to the earliest rate: DAYS = Required Value Date - Earliest Rate Date REQUIRED RATE = Earliest Rate + DAYS * RATEOFCHANGE Straight Line Method As previously stated, there is generally a difference between spot and forward rates. Under the straight line distribution method, this difference, as an amount in local currency, is isolated as a profit or loss at the start of the contract and then simply amortised over the life of the deal as a daily accrual between the appropriate interest profit and loss category code (Interest Paid Exchange or Interest Received Exchange) and the exchange reserve adjustment account. (ACCOUNT.CLASS file = RESERVE). Effectively this deal is now being carried at spot rate (since the forward discount or premium is being accrued) and therefore, it is necessary to revalue it each day just as if it was a spot deal using the technique described in 'Spot Revaluation'. Interest Method The primary factor, influencing the change of forward rates with time, is the real difference in the interest yield of one currency compared with that of the currency for which it is planned to exchange. Example : Assume the yield on GBP is 12% and that on USD is 14% with a Spot rate of 1.25. Then, over 12 months GBP 1000 would yield GBP 120 interest. Likewise, if exchanged (@1.25) USD 1250 would yield USD 175 interest. Thus, in order not to sustain a loss, the 12 month Forward USD sell rate should be (USD 1425/GBP1120) or 1.2723. i.e. USD 1425 * 1.2723 = GBP 1120 In practice, one of the amounts on the Forward deal is held at the same value as for the Spot deal. So, in this example, if the forward deal is also for GBP 1000 the USD amount would be USD 1275 (i.e. USD 1250 plus 2% interest differential thereon of USD 25). Therefore, it is argued that the Discount on the forward USD 12 month rate is simply to offset the 2% USD interest premium prevailing at the time of the deal. This apparent exchange Profit or Loss, therefore, should be accrued over the life of the forward deal as in the manner of the straight line method except that Profit and Loss Interest entries will now be booked for both the currency bought (credit to Interest Received Exchange) and the currency sold (debit to Interest Paid Exchange). Using the same example: A loan of USD 1250 yields USD 175 over 12 months. Over the same time a debit (revaluation) accrual is made of USD 25 (i.e. USD 1250 * 2%). Thus the net result is interest received of USD 150. As proof that this is correct, GBP 1000 at 12% would have given rise to GBP 120 interest, which converted at spot of 1.25 is also USD 150. The effect of this accrual (to discount the forward premium or discount) is to value the position at spot rate so it is, therefore, necessary each day to perform spot revaluation. This method is obviously most appropriate to the transaction type 'Swap' where an actual loan and deposit could be booked with a spot and foward deal and the real interest rates can be used on the forward leg, so rendering the deal entirely neutral. That is, the difference between interest paid and received will be eliminated by the forward accrual and the spot deal will be cancelled, in its effect, by the spot revaluation of the forward leg. Interest/hedged Method Like the interest method, this revaluation type takes into account the difference in the interest yield of one currency compared with that of the currency for which it is exchanged. However, the interest/hedged method bases its interest calculations not on the actual amounts of the deal, but on a 'notional' principal amount on each side (buy & sell). The notional principal amount is that amount which, given the interest rates applicable to each currency of the contract, would yield the actual amounts of the deal over the contract term. In other words, the deal amounts are effectively split into a principal and interest element and it is this interest element which is accrued on each side of the deal over its life. The difference between the interest and interest/hedged methods can be illustrated by example. In all cases, the USD interest rate is 14% and the GBP interest rate is 12%. The spot rate of exchange between the two currencies is 1.25. The forward rates refer to a 12-month forward contract. Example 1 illustrates the figures which have been described under the interest method of revaluation. Example 2 shows a similar deal using the interest/hedged method. Finally, example 3 compares the results of trading a round GBP deal amount, method 'IH', against the original example, method 'IN'. REVALUATION TYPE: 1) IN 2) IH 3) IH USD 'principal': n/a 1,250 1,116 GBP 'principal': n/a 1,000 893 USD interest yield: 178.5 175 156 GBP interest yield: 120 120 107 USD deal amount: 1,275 1,425 1,272 GBP deal amount: 1,000 1,120 1,000 USD/GBP forward rate: 1.275 1.2723 1.2723 This method of calculating interest yields associated with a forward contract is appropriate to a hedging situation where a forward foreign exchange deal is made in cover of balance sheet items. Because the notional principal amounts correspond to an actual spot transaction and are not the same as the resultant forward contract amounts, this revaluation type is not available for use on swap contracts (DEAL TYPE 'SW'). Straight Line Funding Method This method is primarily for the Swap contract type and it is similar to the 'SL' method except that the premium/discount of a Swap is amortised over the life of the deal in the currency that it arises. PM.PARAMETER needs to be changed to include the new position class if the SF reval type is defined on the file FX.REVAL.TYPE. Validation Rules: 2 alpha characters. (Optional input; Default as defined on the FX Deal Type table) Input not allowed for spot deals. Input must relate to a valid method as specified on the FX Reval Type table. For Swap contract type, it works the following way. In a Spot to Forward swap, input is allowed on the forward leg. In a forward to forward swap, input is allowed only in first leg and the value is defaulted to the second leg by system. Validations are performed based on the value present in the field FWD.FWD.SWAP. For forward Internal deals only the revaluation type 'RB' is allowed. Once authorised, the revaluation method cannot be amended. cannot be amended.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The RevaluationType

      • getRoundingRule

        public TField getRoundingRule()
        Returns the RoundingRule

        Field description: This field will hold contract level rounding rule for calculating either amount bought or amount sold. For a given rate and a given amount in either AMOUNT.BOUGHT or AMOUNT.SOLD, the other amount viz. AMOUNT.SOLD or AMOUNT.BOUGHT will be rounded off based on the Rounding Rule. Validation Rules: Should be a valid EB.ROUNDING.RULE id. No change permitted after first authorization Default value is taken from the field ROUNDING.RULE in FX.PARAMETERS For detailed options on different rounding types help text on EB.ROUNDING.RULE file can be referred.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The RoundingRule

      • getSelAccTdateF

        public TField getSelAccTdateF()
        Returns the SelAccTdateF

        Field description: Contains the foreign currency amount of the profit or loss accrued to-date on the 'Swap' or 'Forward' contract where the revaluation type 'IN' or 'IH' has been specified. This field will be increased daily by the amount specified in the daily accrual foreign currency table. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Interest revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.SELL, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in foreign currency) generated by the AMOUNT.SOLD at the INT.RATE.SELL. This field will then be incremented each day by the value of the daily (foreign currency) amount. In the case of Forward contracts done under the interest/hedged revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.SELL, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in foreign currency) generated by the NOTIONAL.SELL.AMT at the INT.RATE.SELL. This field will then be incremented each day by the value of the daily (foreign currency) amount. Example: Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,5773% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the amount sold, i.e. 2,150,000.00 x 75773 x 1 -------------------------- = DEM 452.54 36000 which, converted at the rate of 3.2250, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 140.32. Consequently the value of this field will be DEM 452.54 after the first day, then DEM 905.08 etc. to DEM 83,719.90 on the maturity date. Note: 1. Under the Straight Line revaluation Method, this field will not be activated. 2. More information on the Straight Line and Interest revaluation method can be found in the Help Text for REVALUATION.TYPE. 3. The following rules will be followed for the conversion of the foreign currency accrual amount to its local currency equivalent: - When the contract involves local currency, it will be converted at the contract FORWARD.RATE. - When the contract does not involve the local currency, the BASE currency accrual amount will be converted at the CURRENCY table middle rate and the non-base accrual amount at the contract FORWARD.RATE and the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency. Validation Rules: No input allowed. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SelAccTdateF

      • getSelAccTdateL

        public TField getSelAccTdateL()
        Returns the SelAccTdateL

        Field description: Contains the daily local currency amount of the profit or loss accrued to-date for the 'Swap' or 'Forward' contracts when the revaluation type 'SL', 'IN' and 'IH' has been specified. This field will be increased daily by the amount specified in the daily accrual local currency field. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Straight Line revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the apparent exchange LOSS generated by the forward nature of the transaction. This apparent exchange loss expressed in local currency (i.e. the difference between BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV) will be spread over the period of the contract to provide a per dium accrual amount in local currency. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Interest revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.SELL, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in local currency) generated by the AMOUNT.SOLD at the INT.RATE.SELL.. In both cases, this field will be incremented each day by the value of the daily (local currency) amount. Examples: 1. Straight Line revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,250,000 DEM (the Spot rate being 2.20) The apparent loss, i.e. DEM 50,000.00 will be accrued daily during the 6 month period (185 days in our example) and will generate a daily accrual of DEM 50,000.00 : 185 = DEM 270.27 which, converted at the rate of 3.30, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 81.90 Consequently the value of this field will be GBP 81.90 after the first day, then GBP 163.80 etc. to GBP 15,151.51 (i.e. DEM 50,000.00) on the maturity date. 2. Interest revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,5773% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the amount sold, i.e. 2,150,000.00 x 7,5773 x 1 --------------------------- = DEM 452.54 36000 which, converted at the rate of 3.2250 produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 140.32. Consequently the value of this field will be GBP 140.32 after the first day, then GBP 280.64 etc. to GBP 25,959.60 on the maturity date. Notes: 1. Under the Straight Line revaluation Method, this field will only be activated when the exchange contract has been done with a loss, i.e. the BUY.LCY.EQUIV is smaller (in absolute value) than the SEL.LCY.EQUIV. 2. Under the Interest revaluation method, the difference between the value generated in this field and the value generated in the field BUY.DAILY.ACC.L will correspond exactly to the daily accrual generated under the Straight Line revaluation method. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SelAccTdateL

      • getSelDailyAccF

        public TField getSelDailyAccF()
        Returns the SelDailyAccF

        Field description: Contains the daily foreign currency amount which is to be accrued on those 'Swap' or 'Forward' contracts where the revaluation type 'IN' or 'IH' has been specified. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Interest revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.SELL, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in foreign currency) generated by the AMOUNT.SOLD at the INT.RATE.SELL. In the case of Forward contracts done under the interest/hedged revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.SELL, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in foreign currency) generated by the NOTIONAL.SELL.AMT at the INT.RATE.SELL. Example: Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,5773% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the amount sold, i.e. 2,150,000.00 x 7,5773 x 1 --------------------------- = DEM 452.54 36000 which, converted at the rate of 3.2250, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 140.32. The USD amount of 452.54 will then be recorded in this field. Note: 1. Under the Straight Line revaluation Method, this field will not be activated. 2. More information on the Straight Line and Interest revaluation method can be found in the Help Text for REVALUATION.TYPE. 3. The following rules will be followed for the conversion of the foreign currency accrual amount to its local currency equivalent: - When the contract involves local currency, it will be converted at the contract FORWARD.RATE. - When the contract does not involve the local currency, the BASE currency accrual amount will be converted at the CURRENCY table middle rate and the non-base accrual amount at the contract FORWARD.RATE and the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SelDailyAccF

      • getSelDailyAccL

        public TField getSelDailyAccL()
        Returns the SelDailyAccL

        Field description: Contains the daily local currency amount which is to be accrued on those 'Swaps' or 'Forward' contracts where the revaluation type 'SL', 'IN' or 'IH' has been specified. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Straight Line revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the apparent exchange LOSS generated by the forward nature of the transaction. This apparent exchange loss expressed in local currency (i.e. the difference between BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV) will be spread over the period of the contract to provide a per dium accrual amount in local currency. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the Interest revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.SELL, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in local currency) generated by the AMOUNT.SOLD at the INT.RATE.SELL. In the case of Forward or Swap contracts done under the interest/hedged revaluation method, the amount, which will be generated automatically by the system in this field, will be calculated based on the INT.RATE.SELL, i.e. the daily interest amount (expressed in local currency) generated by the NOTIONAL.SELL.AMT at the INT.RATE.SELL. Examples: 1. Straight Line revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,250,000 DEM (the Spot rate being 2.20) The apparent loss, i.e. DEM 50,000.00 will be accrued daily during the 6 month period (185 days in our example) and will generate a daily accrual of DEM 50,000.00 : 185 = DEM 270.27 which, converted at the rate of 3.30, produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 81.90. This amount will then be recorded in this field. 2. Interest revaluation method Let us suppose a Forward transaction whereby: 6MTH FWD we buy IM USD against 2,150,000 DEM. The spot rate is equal to 2.20 The INT.RATE.BUY is equal to 12% The INT.RATE.SELL is equal to 7,5773% The system will then calculate the daily interest amount on the amount sold, i.e. 2,150,000.00 x 7,5773 x 1 --------------------------- = DEM 452.54 36000 which, converted at the rate of 3.2250 produces a daily accrual in local currency of GBP (local currency) 140.32. This amount will then be recorded in this field. Notes: 1. Under the Straight Line revaluation Method, this field will only be activated when the exchange contract has been done with a loss, i.e. the BUY.LCY.EQUIV is smaller (in absolute value) than the SEL.LCY.EQUIV. 2. Under the Interest revaluation method, the difference between the value generated in this field and the value generated in the field BUY.DAILY.ACC.L will correspond exactly to the daily accrual generated under the Straight Line revaluation method. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SelDailyAccL

      • getSelLcyEquiv

        public TField getSelLcyEquiv()
        Returns the SelLcyEquiv

        Field description: Contains the local currency equivalent of the currency being sold. The field will be calculated by the system and no operator input will be allowed. This local currency equivalent will be used when updating the currency position after successful validation. When Foreign Exchange deals are first entered into the foreign currency position, the local currency equivalent for both the BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV depends on the revaluation method specified in the corresponding contract. The following rules will be adhered to for each one of the revaluation methods below. REBATE METHOD The following rules will be followed: a) When the contract involves local currency It is always the local currency amount [AMOUNT.BOUGHT or AMOUNT.SOLD] which will be used to generate the local currency value in BOTH fields BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV. b) When the contract does not involve local currency The BASE amount of the contract will be converted at contract FORWARD.RATE and the forward rate of the other currency (non base currency) to generate the local currency value in BOTH fields BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV. If for example: SPOT GBP/DEM = 3,30 SPOT GBP/USD = 1,50 FWD 3 MONTH GBP/USD = 1,48 FWD 3 MONTH GBP/DEM = 3,24 the following local currency equivalents will be calculated by the system for the next deals: Deal 1 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 1.48 (Spot Rate) :(1.50) Currency & Amount Sold : GBP 675,675.68 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 01 Revaluation Type : RB SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-675,675.68 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 675,675.68 Deal 2 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 2.18 (Spot Rate) :(2.20) Currency & Amount Sold : DEM 2,180,000.00 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 02 Revaluation Type : RB SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-672,839.51 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 672,839.51 STRAIGHT LINE METHOD The following rules will be followed: a) When the contract involves local currency - The local currency amount of the contract will be kept to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV, i.e: if AMOUNT.BOUGHT = Local currency, then AMOUNT.BOUGHT = BUY.LCY.EQUIV if AMOUNT.SOLD = Local currency, then AMOUNT.SOLD = SEL.LCY.EQUIV - The foreign currency amount of the contract will be converted at the contract SPOT.RATE to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. b) When the contract does not involve local currency - The BASE amount of the contract will be converted at the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency to generate the local Y.EQUIV. - The other foreign currency amount of the contract will be converted at the contract SPOT.RATE and the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. If for example: SPOT GBP/DEM = 3,30 SPOT GBP/USD = 1,50 the following local currency equivalents will be calculated by the system for the next deals: Deal 1 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 1.48 (Spot Rate) :(1.50) Currency & Amount Sold : GBP 675,675.68 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 01 Revaluation Type : SL SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 675,675.68 Deal 2 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 2.18 (Spot Rate) :(2.20) Currency & Amount Sold : DEM 2,180,000.00 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 02 BASE Currency : USD Revaluation Type : SL SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 660,606.06 INTEREST & INTEREST/HEDGED METHODS The same rules as the ones defined for the Straight Line method will be followed, i.e: a) When the contract involves local currency - The local currency amount of the contract will be kept to generate the local currency value in the corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV, i.e: if AMOUNT.BOUGHT = Local currency, then AMOUNT.BOUGHT = BUY.LCY.EQUIV if AMOUNT.SOLD = Local currency, then AMOUNT.SOLD = SEL.LCY.EQUIV - The foreign currency amount of the contract will be converted at the contract SPOT.RATE to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. b) When the contract does not involve local currency - The BASE amount of the contract will be converted at the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. - The other foreign currency amount of the contract will be converted at the contract SPOT.RATE and the CURRENCY table middle rate of the BASE currency to generate the local currency value in its corresponding BUY.LCY.EQUIV or SEL.LCY.EQUIV. If for example: SPOT GBP/DEM = 3,30 SPOT GBP/USD = 1,50 the following local currency equivalents will be calculated by the system for the next deals: Deal 1 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 1.48 (Spot Rate) :(1.50) Currency & Amount Sold : GBP 675,675.68 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 01 Revaluation Type : IN INTEREST.RATE.BUY : 6.964504654 INTEREST.RATE.SELL : 9.75 SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 675,675.68 Deal 2 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 2.18 (Spot Rate) :(2.20) Currency & Amount Sold : DEM 2,180,000.00 Value Date : 6 Months Dealer Desk : 02 BASE Currency : USD Revaluation Type : IN INTEREST.RATE.BUY : 6.00 INTEREST.RATE.SELL : 4.191863385 SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 660,606.06 SPOT CONTRACTS The following rules will be followed: a) Where either the actual amount bought or amount sold happens to be in the local currency of the country (Deal 1), this amount will be adopted as the local currency equivalent for the other currency so that the fields BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV on the main Foreign Exchange contract will contain this same value. It is also this local currency value which will be used to update the Foreign Exchange position once the deal has been successfully validated. b) Where the local currency is neither the currency bought nor the currency sold (Deal 2), the system will calculate the local currency equivalent of the BASE currency/amount and apply it to both currencies of the contract so that BUY.LCY.EQUIV and SEL.LCY.EQUIV on the main Foreign Exchange contract will also contain the same value. To calculate this local currency equivalent of the BASE amount, the system will take the existing middle rate of the base currency as defined on the CURRENCY table. We have supposed here that on the CURRENCY table the middle rate GBP/USD is equal to 1,50. Like in the previous case it is also this local currency equivalent which will be used to update the Foreign Exchange position once the deal has been successfully validated. If for example: SPOT GBP/DEM = 3,30 SPOT GBP/USD = 1,50 the following local currency equivalents will be calculated by the system for the next deals: Deal 1 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 1.5000 Currency & Amount Sold : GBP 666,666.67 Value Date : SPOT Dealer Desk : 01 SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 666,666.67 Deal 2 ------ Currency & Amount Bought : USD 1,000,000.00 Rate of Exchange : 2,2000 Currency & Amount Sold : DEM 2,200,000.00 Value Date : SPOT Dealer Desk : 02 BASE Currency : USD SPOT.LCY.AMT : 666,666.67 BUY.LCY.EQUIV :-666,666.67 SEL.LCY.EQUIV : 666,666.67 Validation Rules: System Generated. Standard Amount Format.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SelLcyEquiv

      • getSendAdvice

        public TField getSendAdvice()
        Returns the SendAdvice

        Field description: Enables the operator to exercise control on the transmission of advices relating to the Foreign Exchange transaction. There are four conditions: N = Normal Transmission H = Hold Transmission P = Send with Priority U = Send with Urgency Validation Rules: 1 character as defined here above. (Optional input; Default value = 'N'.) Input may be only one of the values specified above.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SendAdvice

      • getSendConfirmation

        public TField getSendConfirmation()
        Returns the SendConfirmation

        Field description: Enables the operator to exercise control on the transmission of the confirmation relating to the Foreign Exchange transaction. There are five conditions: N = Normal Transmission H = Hold Transaction P = Send with Priority U = Send with Urgency O = One-sided (do not send). Validation Rules: 1 character as defined here above. (Optional input; Default value = 'N') Input may be only one of the values specified above.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SendConfirmation

      • getSendPayment

        public TField getSendPayment()
        Returns the SendPayment

        Field description: Enables the operator to exercise control on the transmission of payments relating to the Foreign Exchange transaction. There are four conditions: N = Normal Transmission H = Hold Transmission P = Send with Priority U = Send with Urgency Validation Rules: 1 character as defined here above. (Optional input; Default value = 'N'.) Input may be only one of the values specified above.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SendPayment

      • getSodMat

        public TField getSodMat()
        Returns the SodMat

        Field description: Start of Day maturity Entry of "Y" in this field indicates that the maturity processing will take place during Start of Day. Leaving the field blank means that maturity processing will take place at End of Day. This does not affect the sending of maturity payment or advice messages. Validation Rules: Blank or "Y"

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SodMat

      • getSpotDate

        public TField getSpotDate()
        Returns the SpotDate

        Field description: This field is used by the revaluation process to ascertain the starting date to be used for calculating profit or loss on forward contracts using the straight line, interest or interest/hedged revaluation method. This field is used when revaluing forward contracts using the straight line, interest or interest/hedged revaluation method. It contains the start date to be used for the calculation of any profit or loss. The spot date will normally be the deal date plus the number of days required to settle. This is defined on the FX Parameters table in the field Spot Market and will normally be two business days. Validation Rules: Any accepted T24 date format. Input in this field is optional for forward date contracts and its default value will be the Spot market date as defined on FX.PARAMETERS table. The number of days between the deal date and the spot date cannot be greater than the number of days defined in the field SPOT.INTERNAL on the FX.PARAMETERS table. The calculation of default spot date is also controlled by the FX.PARAMETERS fields FX.LCL.REGION and SPOT.BASE.CCY which allow the use of alternative or additional holiday tables. Must be greater than or equal to the deal date.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SpotDate

      • getSpotLcyAmount

        public TField getSpotLcyAmount()
        Returns the SpotLcyAmount

        Field description: This field is generated automatically by the system and will indicate the spot local currency amount. The system will select the base currency and amount and convert it at the CURRENCY table middle rate to provide the spot local currency amount. Validation Rules: Standard amount format. System generated.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SpotLcyAmount

      • getSpotRate

        public TField getSpotRate()
        Returns the SpotRate

        Field description: Identifies the spot exchange rate between the currency bought and currency sold. Spot transactions involve an immediate exchange of one currency for another, and most foreign exchange transactions are of this type. The exchange rate (the price of one currency in terms of another) used on these transactions is known as the spot rate. To allow banks sufficient time to check details and transfer funds, the 'standard' spot value is two business days following the day the deal was struck. This is specified on the FX.PARAMETERS table. Spot may also be defined on this table for internal and central bank reporting. For all spot transactions, input in this field will be mandatory as it represents the contract rate which will be printed on the confirmation sent to the counterparty. The value can also be derived using margin functionality, where Treasury Rate and margin percentage are made available in the contract. For Forward contracts (outright) or Swap contracts (forward leg) using the revaluation method 'SL' (straight line), 'IN' (Interest) or 'IH' (interest/hedged), the spot rate (input or defaulted) will be used to determine and isolate the apparent exchange Profit or Loss amount at the start of the transaction. This exchange Profit or Loss amount will then be amortised over the life of the transaction as a daily accrual between the appropriate interest Profit and Loss category code [Interest Paid Exchange (Category Code 50000) if contract is done at a loss and Interest Received Exchange (Category code 51000) if contract is done at a Profit] and the exchange reserve adjustment internal account. The forward foreign exchange deal will then be carried at spot rate (since the forward rate premium or discount is being amortised/accrued) and, therefore will be revalued each day as if it was a spot deal. The system will check that the rate entered is within the tolerance specified on the Currency table and that the amount bought, amount sold and the rate itself are complementary. (see AMOUNT.BOUGHT) Validation Rules: 1-12 type R (Standard Rate Format - up to 8 integer and 6 decimal) characters plus a decimal point or 1-15 type R (Up to 8 integer and 9 decimal) characters plus a decimal point when EXTENDED.PREC in SPF is set to Y. (Mandatory input except for Forward contracts.) The rate must be in an acceptable format. The rate will be checked against that on the Currency table. If outside the specified tolerance the operator will be asked to confirm the rate by means of entering an override. The rate, amount bought, and amount sold must be complimentary. But, In case if the Treasury rate is entered with Margin Percentage, only one amount is mandatory. Once the deal has been authorised, this field cannot be amended. When the Margin Percentage exists in the contract, Spot rate is non-inputtable.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SpotRate

      • getStmtNo

        public List<TField> getStmtNo()
        Returns the collection of StmtNo

        Field description: A number generated automatically by the system which identifies either a statement entry or a category entry in respect of a contract. The system will automatically insert a number into this field and this number may refer to a statement entry or a category entry depending on the value contained in the corresponding multivalue fields. The following examples will illustrate the use of this field. Example 1: On the value date of a Foreign Exchange contract there will be an entry on the our account pay and the following type of number will be generated at this field: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1 The number automatically generated in Field 104.1 is unique to the contract in question and is built in the following way: 1. The first four digits '6737' indicate the number of days since the 1st of January 1968. In our example, it corresponds to the 11th of June 1986. 2. The next five digits '32684' indicate the number of seconds since midnight. In our example, it corresponds to an entry generated on line at 09:04:44 AM. 3. The last two digits '48' indicate the number of hundreds of seconds. The value assigned (again automatically) to field 154.2 identifies the number in 154.1 as a statement entry number. If the user wishes to call this statement entry record on to the screen the user will invoke the STMT.ENTRY Application and then type the following at 'AWAITING ID': 673732684.480001 where the suffix '0001' identifies it as the first statement entry (there may be more than one as the next example will illustrate). Example 2: A second example outlined here is similar to example 1 in that there is a statement entry on value date for both the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. The system handles this case as follows: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1-2 Once again field 154.1 contains the identification number automatically generated by the system while field 154.2 now contains two separate numbers signifying that there are in fact two separate statement entries, one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. If the user wishes to see either of these he must first of all invoke STMT.ENTRY followed by the desired function and then at 'AWAITING ID' type either: 673732684.480001 where the addition of the suffix '0001' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT PAY or 673732684.480002 where the addition of the suffix '0002' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT RECEIVE. Example 3: A third example might be that of a category entry generated at initiation of a contract where commission or charges have been debited to the customer and credited to a profit and loss category code. In this case the following entries are generated on the contract: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.3 STMT.NO ............ 1 Once again the standard type number is generated and inserted at field 154.1 Now, however, field 154.2 is replaced by Field 104.3 which now identifies the number in 154.1 as a category entry and not a statement entry. To call this category entry record onto the screen the user must now type: CATEG.ENTRY at 'AWAITING APPLICATION' followed by: 673732684.480001 at 'AWAITING ID'. Validation Rules: Internal multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        List<TField> -

      • getStmtNo

        public TField getStmtNo(int idx)
        Returns the StmtNo at the specified position in this collection.

        Field description: A number generated automatically by the system which identifies either a statement entry or a category entry in respect of a contract. The system will automatically insert a number into this field and this number may refer to a statement entry or a category entry depending on the value contained in the corresponding multivalue fields. The following examples will illustrate the use of this field. Example 1: On the value date of a Foreign Exchange contract there will be an entry on the our account pay and the following type of number will be generated at this field: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1 The number automatically generated in Field 104.1 is unique to the contract in question and is built in the following way: 1. The first four digits '6737' indicate the number of days since the 1st of January 1968. In our example, it corresponds to the 11th of June 1986. 2. The next five digits '32684' indicate the number of seconds since midnight. In our example, it corresponds to an entry generated on line at 09:04:44 AM. 3. The last two digits '48' indicate the number of hundreds of seconds. The value assigned (again automatically) to field 154.2 identifies the number in 154.1 as a statement entry number. If the user wishes to call this statement entry record on to the screen the user will invoke the STMT.ENTRY Application and then type the following at 'AWAITING ID': 673732684.480001 where the suffix '0001' identifies it as the first statement entry (there may be more than one as the next example will illustrate). Example 2: A second example outlined here is similar to example 1 in that there is a statement entry on value date for both the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. The system handles this case as follows: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.2 STMT.NO ............ 1-2 Once again field 154.1 contains the identification number automatically generated by the system while field 154.2 now contains two separate numbers signifying that there are in fact two separate statement entries, one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.PAY and one in respect of the OUR.ACCOUNT.RECEIVE. If the user wishes to see either of these he must first of all invoke STMT.ENTRY followed by the desired function and then at 'AWAITING ID' type either: 673732684.480001 where the addition of the suffix '0001' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT PAY or 673732684.480002 where the addition of the suffix '0002' identifies the statement entry in respect of the OUR ACCOUNT RECEIVE. Example 3: A third example might be that of a category entry generated at initiation of a contract where commission or charges have been debited to the customer and credited to a profit and loss category code. In this case the following entries are generated on the contract: 154.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 154.3 STMT.NO ............ 1 Once again the standard type number is generated and inserted at field 154.1 Now, however, field 154.2 is replaced by Field 104.3 which now identifies the number in 154.1 as a category entry and not a statement entry. To call this category entry record onto the screen the user must now type: CATEG.ENTRY at 'AWAITING APPLICATION' followed by: 673732684.480001 at 'AWAITING ID'. Validation Rules: Internal multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        idx - idx of the element to return
        Returns:
        TField -

      • getSwapBaseCcy

        public TField getSwapBaseCcy()
        Returns the SwapBaseCcy

        Field description: On swap transactions one of the amounts of the deal remains constant. That is to say, one of the currencies will have the same amount value on both the spot and forward legs. The purpose of this field is to identify which is that currency. A swap transaction is a contract to buy and sell a currency against another currency with different settlement dates for the two deals. For example, a dealer might decide to sell USD 1,000,000.00 for DEM 2,300,000.00 value spot and buy them back in 6 months time. He may then decide that he wants to buy back the same amount of dollars or to sell back the same amount of Deutsche Marks. The currency code input (or defaulted) in this field will decide which amount remains static on the forward leg. Validation Rules: 3 characters (uppercase alpha) - type SSS or 1-3 numeric characters currency code. (Optional input; Default = base currency) Input is only allowed for deal types SW. The base currency must be the same as either the currency bought or sold. The field cannot be amended once the deal has been authorised.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SwapBaseCcy

      • getSwapPlFwdPos

        public TField getSwapPlFwdPos()
        Returns the SwapPlFwdPos

        Field description: This field specifies a forward position of the premium/discount of a Swap using the 'SF' revaluation type is to be raised or not. The 'SF' revaluation type is similar to the 'SL' except that the premium/ discount of a Swap is accrued in the currency that it arises. Validation Rules: Valid input: YES_NO. (Optional input field.) Default from the file FX.REVAL.TYPE if defined; otherwise default to NO. Input only allowed on 2nd leg of a Swap. YES only allowed with 'SF' revaluation type.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SwapPlFwdPos

      • getSwapRefNo

        public TField getSwapRefNo(int idx)
        Returns the SwapRefNo at the specified position in this collection.

        Field description: This field links together all legs of a swap deal by holding the reference number of each deal. It is generated automatically by the system and no operator input is allowed. On Swap deals, the Foreign Exchange Application will keep on each leg all the reference numbers of the various transactions which are part of the swap deal. This will allow the user to see on any leg of the contract, all other transactions involved in the swap deal. Validation Rules: Standard Foreign Exchange reference number. System generated. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        idx - idx of the element to return
        Returns:
        TField -

      • getSwapRefNo

        public List<TField> getSwapRefNo()
        Returns the collection of SwapRefNo

        Field description: This field links together all legs of a swap deal by holding the reference number of each deal. It is generated automatically by the system and no operator input is allowed. On Swap deals, the Foreign Exchange Application will keep on each leg all the reference numbers of the various transactions which are part of the swap deal. This will allow the user to see on any leg of the contract, all other transactions involved in the swap deal. Validation Rules: Standard Foreign Exchange reference number. System generated. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        List<TField> -

      • getSwiftCommonRef

        public TField getSwiftCommonRef()
        Returns the SwiftCommonRef

        Field description: This is an internal field which is automatically generated by the system when the CPARTY has a SWIFT address defined on the Agency file. This common reference will be used on all messages transmitted through SWIFT. The common reference consists of the SWIFT confirmation address codes of the two counterparties, i.e. ourselves and the CPARTY of the transaction. These codes will appear in alphabetical order. From the CPARTY SWIFT confirmation address specified in the Agency file, the system will automatically select the first four digits plus the seventh and eighth digit. The two codes are separated by four figures from the exchange rate on the contract as agreed by the two counterparties. The exchange rate itself is expressed in the following form: Rate Shown as 2.4560 2456 0.2450 0245 0.2400 0024 24.000 0024 Thus for a Foreign Exchange deal between ourselves with SWIFT confirmation address ABCDEF and a CPARTY with SWIFT address STUVWXYZ at an agreed exchange rate of, say, 15.75 then the Swift Common Reference should be constructed as follows: ABCDEF1575STUVYZ The system will then display the above reference at this field and it would be used on all SWIFT message types relating to this contract and on all the entries generated by Accounting. Validation Rules: A six digit code followed by an exchange ratefollowed by another six digit code. Type SS characters.

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SwiftCommonRef

      • getSyDxReference

        public TField getSyDxReference()
        Returns the SyDxReference

        Field description: A unique reference maintained for trade which will be common for the parent trade and its underlying such as SEC.TRADE/ FOREX/ DX.TRADE. Input to this field will update file SY.DX.LINK.FILE Validation Rules:

        Parameters:
        Returns:
        TField - The SyDxReference

        Parameters:

        TField - The SyTransId

        This field can be used only for Metal Trades. Validation Rules: 1-35 Alpha-numeric characters. Input mandatory for non ISDA type Agreements.

      • getTermsAndConds
