      • setIntFldId

        public void setIntFldId(IntFldIdClass param, int idx)
        Set the specified IntFldId to a specific position in collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.
        Parameters:
        param - the IntFldId to append
        idx - the position in collection
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setIntRateBuy

        public void setIntRateBuy(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for IntRateBuy
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies the interest rate applicable to the currency purchased. The forward exchange rates are usually directly related to the interest rates in the currencies being traded. For example, a Sterling loan receiving 10% funded by a USD deposit paying 12% appears unprofitable. However, the difference in interest rates will be reflected by the Forward Exchange rates with, in this case, the dollar becoming stronger against Pounds Sterling. The currency with a higher interest rate is usually dealt forward on a discount basis while the currency with a lower interest rate will normally be dealt forward with a premium. When the straight line, interest or interest/hedged revaluation method is specified, the system needs to know the interest rates for the two currencies being traded. For this reason on Forward contract, using one of these methods, the foreign exchange application will automatically default the interest rate of the contract BASE.CCY from the PERIODIC INTEREST rate table (prefixed by '01'). The OFFER rate applicable to the currency bought of the forward leg will be selected when the currency bought is the base currency. The BID rate applicable to the currency sold of the forward leg will be selected when the currency sold is the base currency. If the exact period is not found in this table the interest rate of the base currency will then be interpolated. The interest rate applicable to the second currency will then automatically be calculated according to the following formulas:

        1) Calculation of Non Base Interest Rate (IO) Old Formula (Used when the OLD.INT.RATE.CALC field is set to 'YES' and Revaluation type is SL or IN) IO = (100*(PO/NO))*(((RF-RS)/RS)+(IB*NB)/(PB*100))

        2) Calculation of Non Base Interest Rate (IO) New Formula (Used when the OLD.INT.RATE.CALC field is set to Null and Revaluation type is SL, IN or IH. Also used when the OLD.INT.RATE.CALC field is set to YES and Revaluation type is IH) IO= (((100+(IB*NB/PB))*RF/RS)-100)*PO/NO

        where, RS Spot Rate RF Forward Rate IB Interest rate of base currency IO Interest rate of other currency PB Interest day basis for base Ccy PO Interest day basis for other Ccy NB No of days for Interest accruals from spot date (Base Ccy) NO No of days for Interest accruals from spot date (Other Ccy)

        Validation Rules: 1-12 type R (Standard Rate Format - up to 8 integer and 6 decimal) characters plus a decimal point or 1-15 type R (Up to 8 integer and 9 decimal) characters plus a decimal point when EXTENDED.PREC in SPF is set to Y. (Input is optional on Forward contract using the straight line, interest or interest/hedged revaluation method; otherwise not allowed. Default: see details below.) The rate must be in an acceptable format. Input in this field will not be allowed for spot contract. Input in this field will not be allowed on Forward contracts using the 'Rebate' revaluation method.

        The below example sheds more light on the calculation of the Non base interest rates when Reval type is Straight Line/ Interest / Interest Hedged and Old Int Rate Calc is set to Null. The below calculation is also applicable when Reval Type is Interest Hedged and Old Int Rate Calc is set to YES.

        Buy Ccy: USD; Sell Ccy: GBP; Base Ccy: GBP Current T24 date: 20th Apr 2017; Spot Date: 24th Apr 2017; Value Date: 22nd May 2017 Revaluation type: IH; Old Int Rate Calc set to Null

        Description Value Variable
        Spot Rate 1.32 RS
        Forward Rate 1.34 RF
        From Periodic Interest Table of Base Ccy 0.25881 IB
        Interest Day Basis for Base Ccy 365 PB
        Interest day basis for Non Base Ccy 360 PO
        Interest Accrual days for Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NB
        Interest Accrual days for Non Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NO

        IB 0.25881 is defaulted from the periodic interest table. Since in the above example, the base currency is being sold the Bid rate for the respective period is being considered in the INT RATE SELL field. The INT RATE BUY, which is the interest rate of the other currency, is calculated using the formula, IO= (((100+(IB*NB/PB))*RF/RS)-100)*PO/NO Substituting the respective values in the corresponding variables, the INT RATE BUY will be 19.739651784.

        The below example sheds more light on the calculation of the Non base interest rates when Reval type is Straight Line/ Interest and Old Int Rate Calc is set to YES. Buy Ccy: USD; Sell Ccy: GBP; Base Ccy: GBP Current T24 date: 20th Apr 2017; Spot Date: 24th Apr 2017; Value Date: 22nd May 2017 Revaluation type: SL; Old Int Rate Calc set to Yes

        Description Value Variable
        Spot Rate 1.32 RS
        Forward Rate 1.34 RF
        From Periodic Interest Table of Base Ccy 0.25881 IB
        Interest Day Basis for Base Ccy 365 PB
        Interest day basis for Non Base Ccy 360 PO
        Interest Accrual days for Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NB
        Interest Accrual days for Non Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NO

        IB 0.25881 is defaulted from the periodic interest table. Since in the above example, the base currency is being sold the Bid rate for the respective period is being considered in the INT RATE SELL field. The INT RATE BUY, which is the interest rate of the other currency, is calculated using the formula, IO = (100*(PO/NO))*(((RF-RS)/RS)+(IB*NB)/(PB*100)) Substituting the respective values in the corresponding variables, the INT RATE BUY will be 19.735784138.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setIntRateBuy

        public void setIntRateBuy(TField value)
        Set the specified value for IntRateBuy
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies the interest rate applicable to the currency purchased. The forward exchange rates are usually directly related to the interest rates in the currencies being traded. For example, a Sterling loan receiving 10% funded by a USD deposit paying 12% appears unprofitable. However, the difference in interest rates will be reflected by the Forward Exchange rates with, in this case, the dollar becoming stronger against Pounds Sterling. The currency with a higher interest rate is usually dealt forward on a discount basis while the currency with a lower interest rate will normally be dealt forward with a premium. When the straight line, interest or interest/hedged revaluation method is specified, the system needs to know the interest rates for the two currencies being traded. For this reason on Forward contract, using one of these methods, the foreign exchange application will automatically default the interest rate of the contract BASE.CCY from the PERIODIC INTEREST rate table (prefixed by '01'). The OFFER rate applicable to the currency bought of the forward leg will be selected when the currency bought is the base currency. The BID rate applicable to the currency sold of the forward leg will be selected when the currency sold is the base currency. If the exact period is not found in this table the interest rate of the base currency will then be interpolated. The interest rate applicable to the second currency will then automatically be calculated according to the following formulas:

        1) Calculation of Non Base Interest Rate (IO) Old Formula (Used when the OLD.INT.RATE.CALC field is set to 'YES' and Revaluation type is SL or IN) IO = (100*(PO/NO))*(((RF-RS)/RS)+(IB*NB)/(PB*100))

        2) Calculation of Non Base Interest Rate (IO) New Formula (Used when the OLD.INT.RATE.CALC field is set to Null and Revaluation type is SL, IN or IH. Also used when the OLD.INT.RATE.CALC field is set to YES and Revaluation type is IH) IO= (((100+(IB*NB/PB))*RF/RS)-100)*PO/NO

        where, RS Spot Rate RF Forward Rate IB Interest rate of base currency IO Interest rate of other currency PB Interest day basis for base Ccy PO Interest day basis for other Ccy NB No of days for Interest accruals from spot date (Base Ccy) NO No of days for Interest accruals from spot date (Other Ccy)

        Validation Rules: 1-12 type R (Standard Rate Format - up to 8 integer and 6 decimal) characters plus a decimal point or 1-15 type R (Up to 8 integer and 9 decimal) characters plus a decimal point when EXTENDED.PREC in SPF is set to Y. (Input is optional on Forward contract using the straight line, interest or interest/hedged revaluation method; otherwise not allowed. Default: see details below.) The rate must be in an acceptable format. Input in this field will not be allowed for spot contract. Input in this field will not be allowed on Forward contracts using the 'Rebate' revaluation method.

        The below example sheds more light on the calculation of the Non base interest rates when Reval type is Straight Line/ Interest / Interest Hedged and Old Int Rate Calc is set to Null. The below calculation is also applicable when Reval Type is Interest Hedged and Old Int Rate Calc is set to YES.

        Buy Ccy: USD; Sell Ccy: GBP; Base Ccy: GBP Current T24 date: 20th Apr 2017; Spot Date: 24th Apr 2017; Value Date: 22nd May 2017 Revaluation type: IH; Old Int Rate Calc set to Null

        Description Value Variable
        Spot Rate 1.32 RS
        Forward Rate 1.34 RF
        From Periodic Interest Table of Base Ccy 0.25881 IB
        Interest Day Basis for Base Ccy 365 PB
        Interest day basis for Non Base Ccy 360 PO
        Interest Accrual days for Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NB
        Interest Accrual days for Non Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NO

        IB 0.25881 is defaulted from the periodic interest table. Since in the above example, the base currency is being sold the Bid rate for the respective period is being considered in the INT RATE SELL field. The INT RATE BUY, which is the interest rate of the other currency, is calculated using the formula, IO= (((100+(IB*NB/PB))*RF/RS)-100)*PO/NO Substituting the respective values in the corresponding variables, the INT RATE BUY will be 19.739651784.

        The below example sheds more light on the calculation of the Non base interest rates when Reval type is Straight Line/ Interest and Old Int Rate Calc is set to YES. Buy Ccy: USD; Sell Ccy: GBP; Base Ccy: GBP Current T24 date: 20th Apr 2017; Spot Date: 24th Apr 2017; Value Date: 22nd May 2017 Revaluation type: SL; Old Int Rate Calc set to Yes

        Description Value Variable
        Spot Rate 1.32 RS
        Forward Rate 1.34 RF
        From Periodic Interest Table of Base Ccy 0.25881 IB
        Interest Day Basis for Base Ccy 365 PB
        Interest day basis for Non Base Ccy 360 PO
        Interest Accrual days for Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NB
        Interest Accrual days for Non Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NO

        IB 0.25881 is defaulted from the periodic interest table. Since in the above example, the base currency is being sold the Bid rate for the respective period is being considered in the INT RATE SELL field. The INT RATE BUY, which is the interest rate of the other currency, is calculated using the formula, IO = (100*(PO/NO))*(((RF-RS)/RS)+(IB*NB)/(PB*100)) Substituting the respective values in the corresponding variables, the INT RATE BUY will be 19.735784138.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setIntRateSell

        public void setIntRateSell(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for IntRateSell
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies the interest rate applicable to the currency sold. The forward exchange rates are usually directly related to the interest rates in the currencies being traded. For example, a Sterling loan receiving 10% funded by a USD deposit paying 12% appears unprofitable. However, the difference in interest rates will be reflected by the Forward Exchange rates with, in this case, the dollar becoming stronger against Pounds Sterling. The currency with a higher interest rate is usually dealt forward on a discount basis while the currency with a lower interest rate will normally be dealt forward with a premium. When the straight line, interest or interest/hedged revaluation method is specified, the system needs to know the interest rates for the two currencies being traded. For this reason on Forward contract, using one of these methods, the foreign exchange application will automatically default the interest rate of the contract BASE.CCY from the PERIODIC INTEREST rate table (prefixed by '01'). The OFFER rate applicable to the currency bought of the forward leg will be selected when the currency bought is the base currency. The BID rate applicable to the currency sold of the forward leg will be selected when the currency sold is the base currency. If the exact period is not found in this table the interest rate of the base currency will then be interpolated. The interest rate applicable to the second currency will then automatically be calculated according to the following formulas:

        1) Calculation of Non Base Interest Rate (IO) Old Formula (Used when the OLD.INT.RATE.CALC field is set to 'YES' and Revaluation type is SL or IN) IO = (100*(PO/NO))*(((RF-RS)/RS)+(IB*NB)/(PB*100))

        2) Calculation of Non Base Interest Rate (IO) New Formula (Used when the OLD.INT.RATE.CALC field is set to Null and Revaluation type is SL, IN or IH. Also used when the OLD.INT.RATE.CALC field is set to YES and Revaluation type is IH) IO= (((100+(IB*NB/PB))*RF/RS)-100)*PO/NO

        where, RS Spot Rate RF Forward Rate IB Interest rate of base currency IO Interest rate of other currency PB Interest day basis for base Ccy PO Interest day basis for other Ccy NB No of days for Interest accruals from spot date (Base Ccy) NO No of days for Interest accruals from spot date (Other Ccy)

        Validation Rules: 1-12 type R (Standard Rate Format - up to 8 integer and 6 decimal) characters plus a decimal point or 1-15 type R (Up to 8 integer and 9 decimal) characters plus a decimal point when EXTENDED.PREC in SPF is set to Y. (Input is optional on Forward contract using the straight line, interest or interest/hedged revaluation method; otherwise not allowed. Default: see details below.) The rate must be in an acceptable format. Input in this field will not be allowed for spot contract. Input in this field will not be allowed on Forward contracts using the 'Rebate' revaluation method.

        The below example sheds more light on the calculation of the Non base interest rates when Reval type is Straight Line/ Interest / Interest Hedged and Old Int Rate Calc is set to Null. The below calculation is also applicable when Reval Type is Interest Hedged and Old Int Rate Calc is set to YES. Buy Ccy: GBP; Sell Ccy: USD; Base Ccy: GBP Current T24 date: 20th Apr 2017; Spot Date: 24th Apr 2017; Value Date: 22nd May 2017 Revaluation type: IH; Old Int Rate Calc set to Null

        Description Value Variable
        Spot Rate 1.32 RS
        Forward Rate 1.34 RF
        From Periodic Interest Table of Base Ccy 0.25962 IB
        Interest Day Basis for Base Ccy 365 PB
        Interest day basis for Non Base Ccy 360 PO
        Interest Accrual days for Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NB
        Interest Accrual days for Non Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NO

        IB 0.25962 is defaulted from the periodic interest table. Since in the above example, the base currency is being bought the offer rate for the respective period is being considered in the INT RATE BUY field. The INT RATE SELL, which is the interest rate of the other currency, is calculated using the formula, IO= (((100+(IB*NB/PB))*RF/RS)-100)*PO/NO Substituting the respective values in the corresponding variables, the INT RATE SELL will be 19.740462793.

        The below example sheds more light on the calculation of the Non base interest rates when Reval type is Straight Line/ Interest and Old Int Rate Calc is set to YES. Buy Ccy: GBP; Sell Ccy: USD; Base Ccy: GBP Current T24 date: 20th Apr 2017; Spot Date: 24th Apr 2017; Value Date: 22nd May 2017 Revaluation type: SL; Old Int Rate Calc set to Yes

        Description Value Variable
        Spot Rate 1.32 RS
        Forward Rate 1.34 RF
        From Periodic Interest Table of Base Ccy 0.25962 IB
        Interest Day Basis for Base Ccy 365 PB
        Interest day basis for Non Base Ccy 360 PO
        Interest Accrual days for Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NB
        Interest Accrual days for Non Base Ccy from Spot date 28 NO
        IB 0.25962 is defaulted from the periodic interest table. Since in the above example, the base currency is being bought the offer rate for the respective period is being considered in the INT RATE BUY field. The INT RATE SELL, which is the interest rate of the other currency, is calculated using the formula, IO = (100*(PO/NO))*(((RF-RS)/RS)+(IB*NB)/(PB*100)) Substituting the respective values in the corresponding variables, the INT RATE SELL will be 19.736583042.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setIntermedCity

        public void setIntermedCity(TField value)
        Set the specified value for IntermedCity
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Represents the city of the intermediary when the intermediary bank is not known. The values specified will be mapped with SWIFT Option J code "/CITY/". For Example: : If user entered NEWYORK, system will populate it as /CITY/NEWYORK Validation Rules: Input is not allowed when an intermediary number has been entered. Input is allowed to maximum of 34 character If the user enters more than 34 characters, the system would truncate the text

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setIntermedCity

        public void setIntermedCity(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for IntermedCity
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Represents the city of the intermediary when the intermediary bank is not known. The values specified will be mapped with SWIFT Option J code "/CITY/". For Example: : If user entered NEWYORK, system will populate it as /CITY/NEWYORK Validation Rules: Input is not allowed when an intermediary number has been entered. Input is allowed to maximum of 34 character If the user enters more than 34 characters, the system would truncate the text

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

        public void setIntermedName(TField value)
        Set the specified value for IntermedName
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Represents the name of the intermediary when the intermediary bank is not known. The values specified will be mapped with SWIFT Option J code "/NAME/". For Example: If user entered BANK OF NEWYORK, system will populate it as /NAME/BANK OF NEWYORK Validation Rules: Input is not allowed when an intermediary number has been entered. Input is allowed to maximum of 34 character If the user enters more than 34 characters, the system would truncate the text

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:

      • setLeg1FwdRate

        Field description: This field is relevant in leg 2 of a forward to forward swap. It will hold the value of the FORWARD.RATE of leg1. Value in this field is allowed only when DEAL.TYPE is 'SW' and FWD.FWD.SWAP is set as 'YES' Validation Rules: System defaults the value only when the DEAL.TYPE is 'SW' and FWD.FWD.SWAP is set to 'YES' This is a no input field

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setLimitReferenceNo

        public void setLimitReferenceNo(TField value)
        Set the specified value for LimitReferenceNo
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Contains the limit reference number for the counterparty. The reference can be entered by the operator or left blank. If left blank the system will provide the default Limit reference number for FOREX deals. The Limit system covers two main types of exposure as far as the FOREX application is concerned. These are: 1. Overall Foreign Exchange Limit Each deal is monitored against the overall foreign exchange limit of the respective counterparty to ensure that the bank is not overly exposed to this specific counterparty. This overall Foreign Exchange Limit can furthermore be sub-divided to allow definition of Time bands. This would allow to define different limits for Spot and Forward dealing. 2. Clean Risk or Delivery Risk Limit The clean risk limit is the maximum allowable value of foreign exchange transactions from the same counterparty to mature on any single day. For example, the bank may be prepared to have an Overall Foreign Exchange limit of GBP 20 Million with a given counterparty, but may want to limit the delivery risk on any one day to GBP 5 Million. The system does allow for netting of the Overall Foreign Exchange Limit for opposing deals with the same counterparty when the two opposing deals involve the same two currencies and mature on the same day. For example, if the bank buys USD 100,000 from a counterparty for GBP 70,000 to be settled on 31st December and then sells USD 50,000 to the same counterparty for GBP 35,000 to be settled on the same day (December 31st), the net effect would be an overall foreign exchange exposure of USD 50,000. Note that within this approach the Clean Risk is never netted. Validation Rules: Up to 7 numeric characters identifying a valid Limit Reference. (Optional input. Default = As defined on LIMIT.PARAMETER file.) Input is not allowed for internal, negotiated, or broker deals. Any input of a specific limit reference must refer to a FOREX limit type. Once the deal has been authorised this field cannot be amended if NET.OUTSTANDING in LIMIT.PARAMETER has been set as Y.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setLimitReferenceNo

        public void setLimitReferenceNo(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for LimitReferenceNo
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Contains the limit reference number for the counterparty. The reference can be entered by the operator or left blank. If left blank the system will provide the default Limit reference number for FOREX deals. The Limit system covers two main types of exposure as far as the FOREX application is concerned. These are: 1. Overall Foreign Exchange Limit Each deal is monitored against the overall foreign exchange limit of the respective counterparty to ensure that the bank is not overly exposed to this specific counterparty. This overall Foreign Exchange Limit can furthermore be sub-divided to allow definition of Time bands. This would allow to define different limits for Spot and Forward dealing. 2. Clean Risk or Delivery Risk Limit The clean risk limit is the maximum allowable value of foreign exchange transactions from the same counterparty to mature on any single day. For example, the bank may be prepared to have an Overall Foreign Exchange limit of GBP 20 Million with a given counterparty, but may want to limit the delivery risk on any one day to GBP 5 Million. The system does allow for netting of the Overall Foreign Exchange Limit for opposing deals with the same counterparty when the two opposing deals involve the same two currencies and mature on the same day. For example, if the bank buys USD 100,000 from a counterparty for GBP 70,000 to be settled on 31st December and then sells USD 50,000 to the same counterparty for GBP 35,000 to be settled on the same day (December 31st), the net effect would be an overall foreign exchange exposure of USD 50,000. Note that within this approach the Clean Risk is never netted. Validation Rules: Up to 7 numeric characters identifying a valid Limit Reference. (Optional input. Default = As defined on LIMIT.PARAMETER file.) Input is not allowed for internal, negotiated, or broker deals. Any input of a specific limit reference must refer to a FOREX limit type. Once the deal has been authorised this field cannot be amended if NET.OUTSTANDING in LIMIT.PARAMETER has been set as Y.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMarginPerc

        public void setMarginPerc(TField value)
        Set the specified value for MarginPerc
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The value in this field is either defaulted from FX.GROUP.CONDITION ( if the field CUS.MARGIN.DEFAULT in FX.PARAMETER is set to Yes) or User can input a value or override the one defaulted by the system, provided there exists a value in the field "TREASURY.RATE". Validation Rules: No Change field. System raises a validation error when, Both amount bought and sold are given. Contract rate is given with or without amount bought or sold or both.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMarginPerc

        public void setMarginPerc(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for MarginPerc
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The value in this field is either defaulted from FX.GROUP.CONDITION ( if the field CUS.MARGIN.DEFAULT in FX.PARAMETER is set to Yes) or User can input a value or override the one defaulted by the system, provided there exists a value in the field "TREASURY.RATE". Validation Rules: No Change field. System raises a validation error when, Both amount bought and sold are given. Contract rate is given with or without amount bought or sold or both.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMarginPips

        public void setMarginPips(TField value)
        Set the specified value for MarginPips
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Using the values in the fields- Margin.Perc and Treasury. Rate , system calculates the margin amount in terms of PIPS that needs to be added or subtracted to the Treasury Rate to arrive at the Contract/Customer Rate , which then will be used to calculate the Amount bought or sold depending what is inputted by the User. The value can be recalculated by modifying the Margin Percentage given, in case the User needs to. Formula to calculate is = Treasury Rate x Margin Percentage Validation Rules: Noinput field. 1-15 type R Up to 8 integer and 9 decimal

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMarginPips

        public void setMarginPips(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for MarginPips
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Using the values in the fields- Margin.Perc and Treasury. Rate , system calculates the margin amount in terms of PIPS that needs to be added or subtracted to the Treasury Rate to arrive at the Contract/Customer Rate , which then will be used to calculate the Amount bought or sold depending what is inputted by the User. The value can be recalculated by modifying the Margin Percentage given, in case the User needs to. Formula to calculate is = Treasury Rate x Margin Percentage Validation Rules: Noinput field. 1-15 type R Up to 8 integer and 9 decimal

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMetalType

        public void setMetalType(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for MetalType
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description:

        This is mandatory field if one or more of the currencies is a user defined precious metal. This is a user input field denoting the variety of the metal required by the client, out of the following available options:

        GOLD

        SILV

        PLAT

        PALL

        RODH

        RUTH

        OSMI

        IRID

        Validation Rules :

        Mandatory field.

        When GOLD is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should not be GOZ or TOZ.

        When Silver/Palladium/Platinum is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should be only GOZ.

        4 characters (uppercase alpha).

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMetalType

        public void setMetalType(TField value)
        Set the specified value for MetalType
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description:

        This is mandatory field if one or more of the currencies is a user defined precious metal. This is a user input field denoting the variety of the metal required by the client, out of the following available options:

        GOLD

        SILV

        PLAT

        PALL

        RODH

        RUTH

        OSMI

        IRID

        Validation Rules :

        Mandatory field.

        When GOLD is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should not be GOZ or TOZ.

        When Silver/Palladium/Platinum is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should be only GOZ.

        4 characters (uppercase alpha).

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMktgExchAdj

        public void setMktgExchAdj(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for MktgExchAdj
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies the profit adjustment that will be added to the MKTG.EXCH.PROFIT. Any profit relating to the Marketing area is credited to the Profit and Loss category code '53006' with the Profit Centre code of the Counterparty (CUSTOMER). All exchange profit on revaluation will accrue to the Treasury area.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMktgExchAdj

        public void setMktgExchAdj(TField value)
        Set the specified value for MktgExchAdj
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies the profit adjustment that will be added to the MKTG.EXCH.PROFIT. Any profit relating to the Marketing area is credited to the Profit and Loss category code '53006' with the Profit Centre code of the Counterparty (CUSTOMER). All exchange profit on revaluation will accrue to the Treasury area.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMktgExchProfit

        public void setMktgExchProfit(TField value)
        Set the specified value for MktgExchProfit
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies the local currency exchange profit amount taken on the Foreign Exchange transaction which has been allocated to the Marketing Unit. When the CPARTY of the Foreign Exchange transaction has not been defined as a Treasury Customer, the allocation of exchange earnings is made automatically between Treasury and Marketing units at the time of the transaction. Any profit relating to the Marketing area (i.e. Contract rate - Treasury rate) is credited to the Profit and Loss category code '53006' with the Profit Center code of the CPARTY. The offset will be done in the same Profit and Loss Category code with the Profit Centre code of the corresponding Dealer Desk. All exchange profit on revaluation will therefore accrue to the Treasury area. Calculation: 1. Get Treasury rate 2. Calculate non base amount using base amount and Treasury rate. 3. Profit is the difference between calculated non base amount and contract non base amount. 4. Convert difference amount to local currency at middle rate if necessary. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setMktgExchProfit

        public void setMktgExchProfit(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for MktgExchProfit
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies the local currency exchange profit amount taken on the Foreign Exchange transaction which has been allocated to the Marketing Unit. When the CPARTY of the Foreign Exchange transaction has not been defined as a Treasury Customer, the allocation of exchange earnings is made automatically between Treasury and Marketing units at the time of the transaction. Any profit relating to the Marketing area (i.e. Contract rate - Treasury rate) is credited to the Profit and Loss category code '53006' with the Profit Center code of the CPARTY. The offset will be done in the same Profit and Loss Category code with the Profit Centre code of the corresponding Dealer Desk. All exchange profit on revaluation will therefore accrue to the Treasury area. Calculation: 1. Get Treasury rate 2. Calculate non base amount using base amount and Treasury rate. 3. Profit is the difference between calculated non base amount and contract non base amount. 4. Convert difference amount to local currency at middle rate if necessary. Validation Rules: System generated. Standard amount format.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

        public void setNettingStatus(java.lang.CharSequence value)

        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Indicates that the contract has been elected for settlement by a netted payment. (Optional input, Default = Nul, will be elected for settlement by a netted payment if a valid NETTING.AGREEMENT is present for the contract customer) The counterparty for this contract must have a valid netting agreement to enter 'Y'.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setNotes

        public void setNotes(java.lang.CharSequence param, int idx)
        Set the specified Notes to a specific position in collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This element allows the user to record any special information or free form narrative. This narrative is for information only and will not be printed on the confirmation sent to the customer. These notes are for the benefit of the back/front office department and as such will not be output on the confirmation sent to the CPARTY. Validation Rules: 1-4 lines with up to 35 characters in each line.

        Parameters:
        param - the Notes to append
        idx - the position in collection
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setNotionalBuyAmt

        public void setNotionalBuyAmt(TField value)
        Set the specified value for NotionalBuyAmt
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The notional principal amount underlying the contract amount bought. Revaluation method 'IH' only. This field is only used when the interest/hedged revaluation method has been selected for a forward contract (REVALUATION.TYPE, is 'IH'). The value which the system places in this field represents a 'notional' principal amount. This is the amount which, at the given interest rate (INT.RATE.BUY) over the lifetime of the deal, will yield the contract amount (AMOUNT.BOUGHT). This notional amount is used to update currency position records for the buy side of the deal. This contrasts with all other revaluation methods, under which the full contract amount is placed in the forward exchange position. The interest element of the contract amount is amortised and positioned seperately over the life of the deal. The system calculates the NOTIONAL.BUY.AMT according to the following formula: NA = ( A / 100 + ( IR * STV / IDB ) ) * 100 where: NA = notional (buy) amount A = amount (bought) IR = interest rate (currency bought) STV = spot-to-value number of days (currency bought) IDB = interest day basis (currency bought) This figure is, in turn, used to calculate the interest element of the AMOUNT.BOUGHT (by subtraction). Validation Rules: Standard amount format. System generated field.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setNotionalBuyAmt

        public void setNotionalBuyAmt(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for NotionalBuyAmt
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The notional principal amount underlying the contract amount bought. Revaluation method 'IH' only. This field is only used when the interest/hedged revaluation method has been selected for a forward contract (REVALUATION.TYPE, is 'IH'). The value which the system places in this field represents a 'notional' principal amount. This is the amount which, at the given interest rate (INT.RATE.BUY) over the lifetime of the deal, will yield the contract amount (AMOUNT.BOUGHT). This notional amount is used to update currency position records for the buy side of the deal. This contrasts with all other revaluation methods, under which the full contract amount is placed in the forward exchange position. The interest element of the contract amount is amortised and positioned seperately over the life of the deal. The system calculates the NOTIONAL.BUY.AMT according to the following formula: NA = ( A / 100 + ( IR * STV / IDB ) ) * 100 where: NA = notional (buy) amount A = amount (bought) IR = interest rate (currency bought) STV = spot-to-value number of days (currency bought) IDB = interest day basis (currency bought) This figure is, in turn, used to calculate the interest element of the AMOUNT.BOUGHT (by subtraction). Validation Rules: Standard amount format. System generated field.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setNotionalSellAmt

        public void setNotionalSellAmt(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for NotionalSellAmt
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The notional principal amount underlying the contract amount sold. Revaluation method 'IH' only. This field is only used when the interest/hedged revaluation method has been selected for a forward contract (REVALUATION.TYPE, is 'IH'). The value which the system places in this field represents a 'notional' principal amount. This is the amount which, at the given interest rate (INT.RATE.SELL) over the lifetime of the deal, will yield the contract amount (AMOUNT.SOLD). This notional amount is used to update currency position records for the sell side of the deal. This contrasts with all other revaluation methods, under which the full contract amount is placed in the forward exchange position. The interest element of the contract amount is amortised and positioned seperately over the life of the deal. The system calculates the NOTIONAL.SELL.AMT according to the following formula: NA = ( A / 100 + ( IR * STV / IDB ) ) * 100 where: NA = notional (sell) amount A = amount (sold) IR = interest rate (currency sold) STV = spot-to-value number of days (currency sold) IDB = interest day basis (currency sold) This figure is, in turn, used to calculate the interest element of the AMOUNT.SOLD (by subtraction). Validation Rules: Standard amount format. System generated field.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setNotionalSellAmt

        public void setNotionalSellAmt(TField value)
        Set the specified value for NotionalSellAmt
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The notional principal amount underlying the contract amount sold. Revaluation method 'IH' only. This field is only used when the interest/hedged revaluation method has been selected for a forward contract (REVALUATION.TYPE, is 'IH'). The value which the system places in this field represents a 'notional' principal amount. This is the amount which, at the given interest rate (INT.RATE.SELL) over the lifetime of the deal, will yield the contract amount (AMOUNT.SOLD). This notional amount is used to update currency position records for the sell side of the deal. This contrasts with all other revaluation methods, under which the full contract amount is placed in the forward exchange position. The interest element of the contract amount is amortised and positioned seperately over the life of the deal. The system calculates the NOTIONAL.SELL.AMT according to the following formula: NA = ( A / 100 + ( IR * STV / IDB ) ) * 100 where: NA = notional (sell) amount A = amount (sold) IR = interest rate (currency sold) STV = spot-to-value number of days (currency sold) IDB = interest day basis (currency sold) This figure is, in turn, used to calculate the interest element of the AMOUNT.SOLD (by subtraction). Validation Rules: Standard amount format. System generated field.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOldIntRateCalc

        public void setOldIntRateCalc(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for OldIntRateCalc
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The interest rates calculated for 'IN' - Interest revaluation method can use either the old formula as in the previous versions of T24 or use the new formula that is used by the 'IH' - Interest hedge method. This can be controlled by this parameter OLD.INT.RATE.CALC provided on the FOREX application. The system will use the new formula by default and in order to use the old formula the user will have to input a 'YES' into this field. Validation Rules: Optional input. Allowed Values are Null or 'Y'es.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOldIntRateCalc

        public void setOldIntRateCalc(TField value)
        Set the specified value for OldIntRateCalc
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The interest rates calculated for 'IN' - Interest revaluation method can use either the old formula as in the previous versions of T24 or use the new formula that is used by the 'IH' - Interest hedge method. This can be controlled by this parameter OLD.INT.RATE.CALC provided on the FOREX application. The system will use the new formula by default and in order to use the old formula the user will have to input a 'YES' into this field. Validation Rules: Optional input. Allowed Values are Null or 'Y'es.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOptionAmount

        public void setOptionAmount(TField value)
        Set the specified value for OptionAmount
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The amount of the option contract in the OPTION currency. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field and defaulted at input time if the option currency has been defined.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOptionAmount

        public void setOptionAmount(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for OptionAmount
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The amount of the option contract in the OPTION currency. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field and defaulted at input time if the option currency has been defined.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOptionCurrency

        public void setOptionCurrency(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for OptionCurrency
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The currency considered to be the option currency. Validation Rules: Must be equal to the CURRENCY.BOUGHT or the CURRENCY.SOLD No change field Optional Input excepting if OPTION.TYPE is 'MULTI.RATE'

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOptionCurrency

        public void setOptionCurrency(TField value)
        Set the specified value for OptionCurrency
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The currency considered to be the option currency. Validation Rules: Must be equal to the CURRENCY.BOUGHT or the CURRENCY.SOLD No change field Optional Input excepting if OPTION.TYPE is 'MULTI.RATE'

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOptionDate

        public void setOptionDate(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for OptionDate
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Contains the date starting from which partial or total delivery may start for option deals. Most forward contracts have a specific value date. However, commercial customers are not always sure exactly when money is to be received or paid. In these cases the customer may wish to enter into forward contracts allowing for an option period. As an example, UK Ltd sells goods to USA Inc. and expects USD 100,000 in return. In practice UK Ltd knows that USA Inc. takes between 4 and 6 weeks to pay. To enable them to establish how much is to be received, UK Ltd will enter into a 6 week forward contract with an option to settle in 4 weeks time. The bank will quote the rate which is most favourable to them during the option period. Often, when an option deal is set up, the customer will take his option in separate parts. The Foreign Exchange Application allows the user to liquidate option deals in various transactions during the option period i.e. any number of partial deliveries will be allowed during the option period. For further details see separate FOREX section of helptext, 'Option Contracts'. Notes: i) Accruals on Forward contracts using the Straight Line or Interest revaluation method will be calculated from the SPOT.DATE to this date. ii) As soon as the first delivery has taken place during the option period, reversal of the contract will no longer be allowed. Validation Rules: Any date format accepted by T24. The option date must not be later than the value date. The option date must be later than the deal date. The option date must be later than today's date. The option date must be later than the Spot date as defined on the FX.PARAMETERS table on the field SPOT.INTERNAL. The option date must be a business day for the currency involved. Option dates are not allowed for Spot or Swap deals. Option dates are not allowed for Internal or Negotiated deals. Option dates are not allowed when revaluation type is 'IH' (interest/hedged). This field cannot be amended after authorisation.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOptionDate

        public void setOptionDate(TField value)
        Set the specified value for OptionDate
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Contains the date starting from which partial or total delivery may start for option deals. Most forward contracts have a specific value date. However, commercial customers are not always sure exactly when money is to be received or paid. In these cases the customer may wish to enter into forward contracts allowing for an option period. As an example, UK Ltd sells goods to USA Inc. and expects USD 100,000 in return. In practice UK Ltd knows that USA Inc. takes between 4 and 6 weeks to pay. To enable them to establish how much is to be received, UK Ltd will enter into a 6 week forward contract with an option to settle in 4 weeks time. The bank will quote the rate which is most favourable to them during the option period. Often, when an option deal is set up, the customer will take his option in separate parts. The Foreign Exchange Application allows the user to liquidate option deals in various transactions during the option period i.e. any number of partial deliveries will be allowed during the option period. For further details see separate FOREX section of helptext, 'Option Contracts'. Notes: i) Accruals on Forward contracts using the Straight Line or Interest revaluation method will be calculated from the SPOT.DATE to this date. ii) As soon as the first delivery has taken place during the option period, reversal of the contract will no longer be allowed. Validation Rules: Any date format accepted by T24. The option date must not be later than the value date. The option date must be later than the deal date. The option date must be later than today's date. The option date must be later than the Spot date as defined on the FX.PARAMETERS table on the field SPOT.INTERNAL. The option date must be a business day for the currency involved. Option dates are not allowed for Spot or Swap deals. Option dates are not allowed for Internal or Negotiated deals. Option dates are not allowed when revaluation type is 'IH' (interest/hedged). This field cannot be amended after authorisation.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOptionOsAmt

        public void setOptionOsAmt(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for OptionOsAmt
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The remaining amount of the deal in the OPTION currency. This amount is the option amount still to taken down. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field. Defaulted from the BUY or SELL amount initially and recalculated every time there is a take-down.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This field specifies whether the transaction type defined in the field TRANSACTION.TYPE is of a multi rate type, single rate type for option type contracts. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field. Defaulted from the OPTION.TYPE field on the corresponding FX.TRANSACTION.TYPE record.

      • setOsDelBuyAmt

        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This amount corresponds to the outstanding amount in the bought currency that is still available for delivery. In case of Multi-Option Contracts, where the Option Currency is the Currency Sold, this amount is only notional. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:

      • setOsLcyEquivAmt

        public void setOsLcyEquivAmt(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for OsLcyEquivAmt
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The local equivalent amount of the outstanding amount. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field. If a local currency is involved in the deal then this amount will be equal to the outstanding amount in the local currency. If both currencies involved are foreign currencies then this amount will be the local equivalent of the outstanding amount in the base currency.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOsLcyEquivAmt

        public void setOsLcyEquivAmt(TField value)

        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: The local equivalent amount of the outstanding amount. Validation Rules: This is a NOINPUT field. If a local currency is involved in the deal then this amount will be equal to the outstanding amount in the local currency. If both currencies involved are foreign currencies then this amount will be the local equivalent of the outstanding amount in the base currency.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: This field holds the last value date with which the outstanding unused amount was updated in LIMITS. The field is used for the internal workings of LIMITS. Validation Rules: Automatically updated by the system. This is a NOINPUT field.

      • setOverride

        public void setOverride(java.lang.CharSequence param, int idx)
        Set the specified Override to a specific position in collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Contains all the Override messages which the user agreed to during Input. During the validation stage of a Foreign Exchange contract, the system may provide the user with a series of screen override messages to indicate an anomaly, for instance, that the exchange rate varies by more than the variation tolerance defined in the CURRENCY table. In the event that the user confirms the Override, the full text of the actual Override Message will be stored, for reference purposes only, in this multivalue field. For example, if the user inserts an 'abnormal' exchange rate the field corresponding to the exchange rate then when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'VARIANCE OF RATE EXCEEDS PERMITTED TOLERANCE' This will draw the user's attention to the rate entered, which may be a mistake and can then be corrected, or, on the other hand, it may be correct input and so the user confirms that this rate is really intended. A second example might be in respect of a contract done with a client who has a credit line established with the bank but where the maturity date of the intended Foreign Exchange contract goes beyond the credit line expiry date. In this case when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'LINE EXPIRES BEFORE TXN MATURITY' Once again the user's attention is drawn to the situation and either corrected or confirmed via a positive response to the Override Message. If, subsequently, the contract record is either fully displayed or printed, then all override messages will be present. Validation Rules: Internal field. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        param - the Override to append
        idx - the position in collection
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOverride

        public void setOverride(TField param, int idx)
        Set the specified Override to a specific position in collection.
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Contains all the Override messages which the user agreed to during Input. During the validation stage of a Foreign Exchange contract, the system may provide the user with a series of screen override messages to indicate an anomaly, for instance, that the exchange rate varies by more than the variation tolerance defined in the CURRENCY table. In the event that the user confirms the Override, the full text of the actual Override Message will be stored, for reference purposes only, in this multivalue field. For example, if the user inserts an 'abnormal' exchange rate the field corresponding to the exchange rate then when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'VARIANCE OF RATE EXCEEDS PERMITTED TOLERANCE' This will draw the user's attention to the rate entered, which may be a mistake and can then be corrected, or, on the other hand, it may be correct input and so the user confirms that this rate is really intended. A second example might be in respect of a contract done with a client who has a credit line established with the bank but where the maturity date of the intended Foreign Exchange contract goes beyond the credit line expiry date. In this case when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'LINE EXPIRES BEFORE TXN MATURITY' Once again the user's attention is drawn to the situation and either corrected or confirmed via a positive response to the Override Message. If, subsequently, the contract record is either fully displayed or printed, then all override messages will be present. Validation Rules: Internal field. Multivalue field.

        Parameters:
        param - the Override to append
        idx - the position in collection
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setOwnBookPort

        public void setOwnBookPort(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for OwnBookPort
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting information to a Trade Repository. Denotes the Banks own book portfolio ID Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed and for FW or SW types FX contracts or when SUB.DEAL.TYPE is not 'IN' Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field The own book portfolio should be a valid SEC.ACC.MASTER record and also be an own book The logic to update the Portfolio with the trade details will be introduced in the next phase of OC module development.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

        Set the specified value for PortCompression
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting information to a Trade Repository. Specifies if the trade is as a result of a portfolio compression event Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed and for FW or SW type FX contracts or when SUB.DEAL.TYPE is not 'IN' Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field Allowed optional values are Y or N or NULL Y denotes that the contract results from a portfolio compression event N denotes that the contract is not due to portfolio compression event

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setPositionTypeBuy

        public void setPositionTypeBuy(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for PositionTypeBuy
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies the position type applicable to the foreign exchange transaction. This facility is not used at present. Typically any bank will maintain a 'TRADING' position which will reflect the net position of all dealing and back office activity. On the other side, the management of the bank could also decide, from time to time, to take a position outside the normal trading activity and which consequently will not be included in the day to day trading activity and position but instead in a separate position which will generally be called 'Management' position. This position will then be under the exclusive control of the management itself and will only consist of a very small number of foreign exchange deals (1 or 2). For the dealing room trader this management position will be transparent as it is normally outside his area of responsibility. Any foreign exchange deal where the position type 'Management' has been indicated, must be classified as internal and will update at the same time and in the opposite sense the Management position and the Trading position. The foreign exchange dealer will then make a second deal in the market to cover his own trading position. Only the Management position will then exist at this stage. When management decides to liquidate or undo this position, the reverse operation will take place. Before a type can be entered it must first be created on the FX Pos Type table. Example: Let us suppose that the management believes that the U.S. dollar will go down against the Deutsche Mark in the near future and that, for this reason, decides to sell one month forward 10 million dollars against Deutsche Mark. The following deals will then be created: 1) Internal deal between trader and management. The trader will buy dollars from management and sell Deutsche Mark to management which consequently will be short in dollars and long in Deutsche Marks. To keep the cost of the trading position intact, the exchange rate applicable to this transaction will normally be the rate agreed in the next deal (external deal). 2) The trader, to keep intact his trading position will make an opposite contract in the market for the same amount, rate and maturity date. The following position will then exist across the books of the bank: Trading Position ---------------- DEM USD - = SELL to management + = BUY from management + = BUY from the market - = SELL in the market _______________________ _______________________ SQUARE POSITION SQUARE POSITION Management Position ------------------- DEM USD + = BUY from trader - = SELL to trader ______________________ _____________________ Long in DEM Short in USD During the revaluation process, separate accounting entries will be generated for the Management position to strictly isolate any exchange Profit or Loss which will result from this position. Validation Rules: 2 characters. (Optional input; Default = TR for Trading) The code entered must appear on the FX.POS.TYPE table (see General Tables). Once authorised the field cannot be amended.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setPositionTypeBuy

        public void setPositionTypeBuy(TField value)
        Set the specified value for PositionTypeBuy
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies the position type applicable to the foreign exchange transaction. This facility is not used at present. Typically any bank will maintain a 'TRADING' position which will reflect the net position of all dealing and back office activity. On the other side, the management of the bank could also decide, from time to time, to take a position outside the normal trading activity and which consequently will not be included in the day to day trading activity and position but instead in a separate position which will generally be called 'Management' position. This position will then be under the exclusive control of the management itself and will only consist of a very small number of foreign exchange deals (1 or 2). For the dealing room trader this management position will be transparent as it is normally outside his area of responsibility. Any foreign exchange deal where the position type 'Management' has been indicated, must be classified as internal and will update at the same time and in the opposite sense the Management position and the Trading position. The foreign exchange dealer will then make a second deal in the market to cover his own trading position. Only the Management position will then exist at this stage. When management decides to liquidate or undo this position, the reverse operation will take place. Before a type can be entered it must first be created on the FX Pos Type table. Example: Let us suppose that the management believes that the U.S. dollar will go down against the Deutsche Mark in the near future and that, for this reason, decides to sell one month forward 10 million dollars against Deutsche Mark. The following deals will then be created: 1) Internal deal between trader and management. The trader will buy dollars from management and sell Deutsche Mark to management which consequently will be short in dollars and long in Deutsche Marks. To keep the cost of the trading position intact, the exchange rate applicable to this transaction will normally be the rate agreed in the next deal (external deal). 2) The trader, to keep intact his trading position will make an opposite contract in the market for the same amount, rate and maturity date. The following position will then exist across the books of the bank: Trading Position ---------------- DEM USD - = SELL to management + = BUY from management + = BUY from the market - = SELL in the market _______________________ _______________________ SQUARE POSITION SQUARE POSITION Management Position ------------------- DEM USD + = BUY from trader - = SELL to trader ______________________ _____________________ Long in DEM Short in USD During the revaluation process, separate accounting entries will be generated for the Management position to strictly isolate any exchange Profit or Loss which will result from this position. Validation Rules: 2 characters. (Optional input; Default = TR for Trading) The code entered must appear on the FX.POS.TYPE table (see General Tables). Once authorised the field cannot be amended.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setPreUtiId1

        public void setPreUtiId1(TField value)
        Set the specified value for PreUtiId1
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting information to a Trade Repository. Denotes the Previous UNI.TRAN.ID value. When UNI.TRAN.ID is changed , it replaces the previous one and the previous one is moved into this field. Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed and for FW or SW type FX contracts or when SUB.DEAL.TYPE is not 'IN' Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field Can contain upto 52 alphanumeric characters

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setPreUtiId1

        public void setPreUtiId1(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for PreUtiId1
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting information to a Trade Repository. Denotes the Previous UNI.TRAN.ID value. Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed and for FW or SW type FX contracts or when SUB.DEAL.TYPE is not 'IN' Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field Can contain upto 52 alphanumeric characters

        value - The value to set

      • setPreUtiId2

        Set the specified value for PreUtiId2
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting information to a Trade Repository. Denotes the Previous PRE.UTI.ID.1 value. When UNI.TRAN.ID is changed, it replaces the previous one and the previous value in PRE.UTI.ID.1 is moved into this field. Input to this field is allowed only when OC module is installed and for FW or SW type FX contracts or when SUB.DEAL.TYPE is not 'IN' Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field Can contain upto 52 alphanumeric characters

        public void setPreUtiId2(TField value)
        Set the specified value for PreUtiId2
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Part of Regulatory Reporting information to a Trade Repository. Denotes the Previous PRE.UTI.ID.1 value.         value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setPvpSettlement

        public void setPvpSettlement(TField value)
        Set the specified value for PvpSettlement
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Specifies whether the FX Contract is settled through Payment Versus Payment Settlement process and corresponds to the TAG 17I in MT300. PVP arrangement allows two currencies in an FX contract to be exchanged simultaneously on a central Settlement Platform to eliminate the Settlement Risk. To apply PVP, both the parties involved in the FX Contract need to have a pre-agreement with the CENTRAL SETTLEMENT PLATFORM. For Example, A USD/MYR FX deal requires both the parties to have an agreement to settle via HK Interbank Clearing Ltd. Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field Valid values are Y or N or Null N or NULL represents that the FX transaction is not PVP Y represents that the FX transaction is PVP Input not allowed for metal trade

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setPvpSettlement

        public void setPvpSettlement(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for PvpSettlement
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Specifies whether the FX Contract is settled through Payment Versus Payment Settlement process and corresponds to the TAG 17I in MT300. PVP arrangement allows two currencies in an FX contract to be exchanged simultaneously on a central Settlement Platform to eliminate the Settlement Risk. To apply PVP, both the parties involved in the FX Contract need to have a pre-agreement with the CENTRAL SETTLEMENT PLATFORM. For Example, A USD/MYR FX deal requires both the parties to have an agreement to settle via HK Interbank Clearing Ltd. Validation Rules: This is an OPTIONAL field Valid values are Y or N or Null N or NULL represents that the FX transaction is not PVP Y represents that the FX transaction is PVP Input not allowed for metal trade

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setQuantity

        public void setQuantity(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for Quantity
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description:

        This is a mandatory field if one or more of the currencies is a user defined precious metal. This is a user input field denoting the type of unit, in which the precious metal is to be transferred or delivered, out of the following options :

        FOZ

        GOZ

        GRM

        KLO

        LOT

        TAL

        TOL

        TOZ

        UNT

        Validation rules :

        Mandatory Field.

        When GOLD is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should not be GOZ or TOZ (GOZ and TOZ not supported for GOLD Metal type).

        When Silver/Palladium/Platinum is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should be only GOZ.

        3 alpha characters.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setQuantity

        public void setQuantity(TField value)
        Set the specified value for Quantity
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description:

        This is a mandatory field if one or more of the currencies is a user defined precious metal. This is a user input field denoting the type of unit, in which the precious metal is to be transferred or delivered, out of the following options :

        FOZ

        GOZ

        GRM

        KLO

        LOT

        TAL

        TOL

        TOZ

        UNT

        Validation rules :

        Mandatory Field.

        When GOLD is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should not be GOZ or TOZ (GOZ and TOZ not supported for GOLD Metal type).

        When Silver/Palladium/Platinum is involved as metal type in the transaction, then the quantity of the metal should be only GOZ.

        3 alpha characters.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setRealiseFixPl

        public void setRealiseFixPl(TField value)
        Set the specified value for RealiseFixPl
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Specifies if the Profit and Loss from the deal is to be realised if the 2 currencies involved are linked to a fixed currency (i.e the EURO). Profit and Loss will be realised on the night before the fixed rate applies. There is no subsequent revaluation or accrual for the deal. When profit and loss is realised the existing unrealised P&L is backed out and is posted to the categories specified in REVALUATION.PARAMETER in the fields PRFT.FIX.CAT and LOSS.FIX.CAT, the exchange adjustment entries are posted to internal accounts of the category held in the fields PRFT.FIX.INT.CT and LOSS.FIX.INT.CT. For revaluation types SL, IN, IH and SF the remaining accrual is made on the night of realisation. Validation Rules: Optional input. Valid input of Y only. Input of Y only allowed if 2 currencies have a FIXED.CCY defined.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setRealiseFixPl

        public void setRealiseFixPl(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for RealiseFixPl
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Specifies if the Profit and Loss from the deal is to be realised if the 2 currencies involved are linked to a fixed currency (i.e the EURO). Profit and Loss will be realised on the night before the fixed rate applies. There is no subsequent revaluation or accrual for the deal. When profit and loss is realised the existing unrealised P&L is backed out and is posted to the categories specified in REVALUATION.PARAMETER in the fields PRFT.FIX.CAT and LOSS.FIX.CAT, the exchange adjustment entries are posted to internal accounts of the category held in the fields PRFT.FIX.INT.CT and LOSS.FIX.INT.CT. For revaluation types SL, IN, IH and SF the remaining accrual is made on the night of realisation. Validation Rules: Optional input. Valid input of Y only. Input of Y only allowed if 2 currencies have a FIXED.CCY defined.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setReplacingDealNo

        public void setReplacingDealNo(java.lang.CharSequence value)
        Set the specified value for ReplacingDealNo
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies a previous contract which has been reversed (due to an error) and which is replaced by this new transaction. This information is used with the narrative 'AMEND' on a SWIFT confirmation and is placed in Field 21 of an MT300. If it is not present on a new input, this indicates a 'new' MT300. Validation Rules: Up to 10 numeric characters. (Mandatory input when CORR.AMEND.MKR = 'A'; Optional input when CORR.AMEND.MKR = 'C'; Otherwise not allowed.) The deal number must exist on the history file in reverse status. Must be with the same CPARTY as an original deal.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing

      • setReplacingDealNo

        public void setReplacingDealNo(TField value)
        Set the specified value for ReplacingDealNo
        Throws an UnsupportedOperationException if the object is not modifiable.

        Field description: Identifies a previous contract which has been reversed (due to an error) and which is replaced by this new transaction. This information is used with the narrative 'AMEND' on a SWIFT confirmation and is placed in Field 21 of an MT300. If it is not present on a new input, this indicates a 'new' MT300. Validation Rules: Up to 10 numeric characters. (Mandatory input when CORR.AMEND.MKR = 'A'; Optional input when CORR.AMEND.MKR = 'C'; Otherwise not allowed.) The deal number must exist on the history file in reverse status. Must be with the same CPARTY as an original deal.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        nothing
